name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 17 September 2020.

name: Presidente. –
text: It is with deep regret that we have seen in recent days the devastating floods in south-east France and north-west Italy: several people have died and many are still missing. We pay tribute to the victims and, of course, send our condolences to the families and people affected.  We express our solidarity and respect for the work done by the Civil Protection rescue teams, who continue to assist the victims, search for missing persons and help the communities that have been affected in this way in recent days.

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 1 October 2020. The following amendments have been tabled: I have received three requests for urgent procedure under Rule 163 of the Regulation to add the following legislative documents to be adopted during this part-session: – application of rail safety and interoperability rules in the Channel Tunnel; - decision authorising France to conclude an international agreement on the Channel Tunnel; – organic production: date of application and some other dates. These requests will be put to the vote today in the first round of voting. Under the Rules of Procedure, only the authors of the requests and one speaker against, as well as the chairmen or rapporteurs of the relevant committees, may be heard. Is there anyone in the Chamber who wishes to speak on one of the requests for urgent procedure? Then there's no one there. With regard to two Council positions on the markets for financial instruments and on European providers of crowdfunding services for companies, I would like to inform the House that no proposals have been submitted to reject the Council's positions, nor have amendments been tabled pursuant to Articles 67 and 68 of the regulation. The proposed acts are therefore deemed to have been adopted.  Finally, the votes were distributed in different voting rounds. This distribution may be subject to change depending on the number of amendments and the number of requests for split and separate votes. Information on the distribution of votes is available on the European Parliament's website, in the "Priority Information and Documents" section. Finally, following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal for an amendment to the final draft agenda: Wednesday The title of the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on 'The resumption of hostilities between Armenia and Arzerbaigian in relation to the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh' is as follows. "The resumption of hostilities between Armenia and Arzerbaigian in relation to the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict"." Are there any objections? The amendment is thus approved.

name: Sylvia Limmer (ID).

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Michal Šimečka, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (2020/2072(INI)) (A9-0170/2020).

name: Michal Šimečka
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, we are of course here to discuss the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, but what we are really discussing – and should be debating – is the very future identity of the EU as a democratic peace project. I grew up in Slovakia in the years after the Velvet Revolution. For people of my generation membership of the European Union basically meant a guarantee of life in freedom and democracy. The EU was meant to be a place where you don’t get imprisoned if you speak out freely, which is what the Communist regime did to my grandfather, who was a dissident intellectual. The EU was meant to be a place where you don’t get thrown out of your job for disagreeing with those in power, which is what happened to other members of my family. But the problem is that this image of the EU, the image of my youth, the image of the EU as a guardian of democracy is now being shattered and instead it has developed a very high tolerance – an unacceptably high tolerance – for authoritarian politics. We have at least one Member State which can no longer be considered a democracy; we have another Member State – Poland – in which judges can be prosecuted for a verdict against the interests of the ruling party; and, in many other Member States, we have thousands on the street protesting against years of corruption and state capture, all of which begs the question where has the EU been while national governments have undermined democratic institutions or plundered public resources? The proposal that we put before the plenary should put the EU in a position to do much more. What we need is a permanent, legally binding mechanism that, first of all, streamlines and makes more effective the rule of law instruments that we have; second, covers all aspects of Article 2 and all values enshrined there; and, third, ensures that compliance by Member States is not just reviewed periodically but also enforced. Enforcement action is precisely what has so far also been missing from the Commission’s otherwise thorough and very welcome report last week. But it is clear that monitoring alone will not bring back judicial independence in Poland, nor will it save the Index media in Hungary. We really we do need enforcement. For instance, in Poland, the Commission still hasn’t come up with a request to impose fines, despite the fact that the Polish Government is disrespecting the ruling of the European Court of Justice, and we can continue on and on. But, equally importantly, the Council needs to stop diluting the budget conditionality proposal. We know that EU money has demonstrably fuelled the rise of authoritarian and corrupt politics in our Member States and this cannot continue. But the problem is that it will continue if the proposal of the German Presidency is adopted because it is weak and will not protect either the EU budget or the rule of law in Europe. If the Commission and the Council are serious about restoring the EU as a community of shared values, I would expect them immediately to begin negotiations on the proposal that Parliament is putting forward for a binding mechanism as soon as possible. We know that there will be pushback and we know that some Member States might reject it outright, seeing as they are willing to hold the entire continent hostage to rule of law conditionality, but there is a piece of good news as well. The Council only needs a qualified majority to negotiate and adopt our proposal and therefore reclaim some of the EU’s aspiration for a democratic project. (Applause)

name: Tiemo Wölken
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are facing an ever-increasing crisis of fundamental values in the European Union, a crisis that could jeopardise the survival of the European Union. Nothing less than the survival of the European Union is at stake if journalists are attacked in the European Union, corruption is not combated, the independence of the judiciary is jeopardised. It is therefore right that the Commission should produce an annual report on the rule of law, but it is an aberration that this report lacks the aspects of fundamental rights and democracy. How else should we tackle this when, for example, LGBTQI-free zones are created in a Member State? We therefore need the monitoring mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights called for in this report. This mechanism is effective when it is underlined with a strong conditionalisation in the budget. That is what we will continue to fight for. The enemies of the rule of law find their fiercest resistance here in this House. I would like to thank Michal for the very good cooperation between the committees and, in particular, for the inclusion of important points relating to whistleblower protection, the promotion and training of legal professionals and for the support for the financing of such important projects in the MFF.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s an honour to be here with you today to speak about our Parliament’s proposal for a Mechanism on Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights. Let me first thank the rapporteur, Mr Šimečka, for his work dedicated to defending the fundamental values of the EU and such a comprehensive report. President von der Leyen said it clearly in her State of the Union speech of a few days ago. Mutual trust is at the very heart of the Union and the way we do things together. Breaches of the rule of law cannot be tolerated, and we will continue to defend the rule of law and the integrity of our European institutions. European values are not for sale. We share the objectives of the proposals of the Parliament to set a positive agenda for promoting, protecting and reinforcing Union values in accordance with Article 2 of the Treaty. This also corresponds to the objectives of the Commission for a new push for European democracy, including the first annual rule of law report published on 30 September as part of the new Comprehensive European Rule of Law Mechanism, and the Commission is well aware of the request of the Parliament for a broader mechanism covering not only the rule of law but also democracy and fundamental rights. I would like to underline, then, that the scope of the rule of law mechanism is already comprehensive, as it is covering four areas: the national justice systems; the anti-corruption frameworks; media pluralism and media freedom; and other institutional issues related to checks and balances. The wide scope covers issues which are particularly important for the European Parliament, such as the enabling framework for civil society. All these aspects contribute also to the promotion of democracy and respect of fundamental rights. In the next years, the Commission will consider consolidating its monitoring in these areas and could cover additional aspects. The Commission also recognises the necessity to further promote democracy and respect for fundamental rights. We believe that it requires a diversity of tailor-made approaches and instruments. As regards fundamental rights, the Commission intends to present, still this year, the new strategy for the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Particular attention will be given to the application of the Charter in the Member States and impact on citizens daily lives. And also by the end of this year, the Commission will present another flagship initiative – the European Democracy Action Plan – which will focus on countering disinformation and adapting to evolving threats and manipulations, as well as supporting free and independent media. The European Democracy Action Plan will specifically contribute to upholding fundamental rights and strengthening democracies through three integrated themes. They are: elections’ integrity; the second is strengthening freedom of expression and democratic debate; and the third theme is tackling disinformation in a coherent manner considering the need to look together at all the means used to interfere in our democratic system. The Action Plan will also have a particular focus on citizens’ participation and the role of civil society. Other initiatives and strategies will also further promote our basic foundations, for instance the forthcoming EU citizenship report and other strategies to build a Union of equality. The Commission will continue to monitor the impact of measures adopted in the context of the COVID-19 crisis as regards compliance with EU law and ensuring free and fair elections and a fair democratic debate until restrictions are lifted. As regards more specifically the concrete Parliament proposals for the rule-of-law monitoring and its follow-up, I will now give the floor to Commissioner Reynders.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Grazie, Presidente. Honourable Members, I would like to reinforce, if it’s possible, what Vice—President Jourová just said: the Commission fully agrees with the European Parliament with regard to the importance of strengthening the EU’s capacity to monitor respect of our common values.  For this reason, the Commission presented last week – as was said by the rapporteur, Mr Šimečka, and thank you for your report – its first annual report on the rule of law, at the centre of a comprehensive European rule of law mechanism. The mechanism is broader than just the report. The mechanism is a yearly process with the aim to prevent problems from emerging or deepening, notably by having open debates and by changing best practices.  The aim of the rule of law report is to look at key developments as regards the rule of law across the whole European Union. It covers both positive developments and challenges, and provides a country—specific assessment of all the 27 Member States.  With regard to the methodology as proposed by the Parliament for the annual monitoring cycle, the Commission agrees on the importance of the consultation of stakeholders and on using a variety of sources, including via visits in the Member States. This has been the approach already for the first annual rule of law report. All the Member States provided written input and we also carried out a targeted stakeholder consultation where over 200 stakeholders provided written input. We also conducted more than 300 virtual country visits, meeting with Member State national authorities, with judicial and other independent authorities and with relevant stakeholders, including civil society organisations. We made sure that this process was robust, transparent and inclusive. We have also kept the Parliament fully informed of all progress. This report represents the Commission’s assessment, but it relies also on assessments prepared by a variety of independent experts and bodies, including the Fundamental Rights Agency and the Council of Europe.  Let me also say a few words on the follow—up to the report. Its aim is to kick-start an inclusive debate at European and national level. I know that is precisely one of the objectives of the draft report of the European Parliament discussed today. In this respect, we welcome in particular the proposal that the Parliament and the Council discuss the content of the annual report presented by the Commission. We should maximise this momentum to bring about change in the Union.  In this regard I know technical preparations in Parliament have started too. Your first meetings with national parliaments are in October, November. I can only welcome this as a very positive development. We are committed to work on strengthening the cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council through regular meetings and exchanges of views in order to build this process together in an inclusive and constructive way.  We have a common interest to swiftly set up the rule of law mechanism, and the publication of the rule of law report last week is an important first step towards this objective. Pursuing this under the existing institutional arrangements would ensure the effectiveness of our cooperation. We should develop our modus operandi step by step. Whether in the future such cooperation should be codified in an interinstitutional agreement will have to be assessed at a later stage on the basis of the experience gained through the application of the European rule of law mechanism. So we will continue a permanent debate year after year on the basis of the next report, and maybe we’ll try to organise better cooperation, year after year among the two institutions.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa
text: replacing the draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, thanks to my colleague, Mr Cimoszewicz, who cannot be here today and so I speak instead. Actually, ladies and gentlemen, nothing characterizes our Union more than its values. And therefore, with this first report by the European Commission on the rule of law, we can say that we open — modestly, everything is improveable — a new stage; a stage that is no longer just that of the Stability and Growth Pact, that of fiscal and budgetary rules and that of the European Semester, but the era , hopefully – of the semester or the annual cycle of rights. I also welcome the legislative initiative report drawn up by Parliament, which proposes precisely what the Commissioner alluded to in his final part of the speech: that interinstitutional agreement which is essential in order to be able to effectively defend the rights and values of the Union. One last thought: it is very important that, where this mechanism for the rule of law identifies serious breaches of Article 2, infringement proceedings before the Court of Justice and, where appropriate, budgetary conditionality and the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty are put in place by the Commission.

name: Vladimír Bilčík
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, former Czechoslovak President, Václav Havel, would have been 84 today. So let me begin my remarks by reminding all of us of Havel’s words, and I quote: ‘Keep the company of those who seek the truth, run from those who have found it.’ Havel saw the truth his whole life, often doubting his own thoughts. He believed in reflection, critical thinking and honest discussion – something that Communism forbade for decades and something that Havel saw as the essence of a free and democratic Europe. He believed in an open Europe and worked relentlessly and successfully for the return of central Europeans to our common European project. So let’s think of people like Havel and the Europe of the past, divided and weak, as we discuss the current need for an effective mechanism on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights. Europe must protect common democratic principles and the sense of European justice in order to maintain its purpose and have a meaningful future. Today’s discussion is about fundamentals, which we must monitor, guard and protect diligently, but also fairly, with respect to all Member States. This mechanism is not about a single country or the naming and shaming of particular individuals. It is about the essential foundations of democracy and institutions that should work for the benefit of all Europeans. I want to thank the rapporteur for steering our work on this report along these lines. We have a solid text and we should send a strong message from this House this week to the Council and the Commission about the necessity for joint ownership and joint protection of rule of law. In Havel’s words, all European institutions should keep our company in search of a more just and more democratic European Union. (Applause)

name: Katarina Barley
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, 80% of Europeans think that the rule of law has great importance and that it should be enforced in the European Union. The European Parliament has being calling for such monitoring for a long time now. Already in 2016 we delivered a report on that matter and since then the situation in the Member States has not become any better.  Now we have the report of the Commission – thank you very much for it. We still believe that our report – thank you to Michal Šimečka and the other shadows – goes further, especially in scope but also concerning independent experts and an automatic reaction to the breaches. Still, we are happy that this report is here and we are also happy with the way it has been presented, using very clear language. It is good because now we can compare, and as for the argument of ‘well, here we do the same as this country and that country’, we can now see the bigger picture. And you have to look at all of it.  As for the key questions – ‘do you, as a government, want to be controlled?’ ‘Do you believe that criticism is something positive that brings you further in democracy?’ – I am deeply convinced that we can compromise on everything – on posts, on persons, on money, on budget, on everything – but we can never compromise on our core values. We have to be very clear on this. We have the values in the treaty. We have the European Court of Justice that rules on it and there we are not willing to compromise on anything.  (Applause)

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur for doing an excellent job in getting a very large majority behind this very important report. I am quite proud to be a member of a House which has always been the champion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Four years ago, almost to the day, this House adopted the first proposal for an annual report covering all the Member States, because we see in Europe today – but we also see it across the Atlantic – that the democratic rule of law is actually quite vulnerable to attacks from the inside. We are protecting ourselves from attacks from the outside, but there are attacks from the inside, and that is why we need to strengthen the toolkit to uphold the values laid down in the Treaties.  I would like to thank both Commissioners for putting forward an excellent report last week, but we are going to take it one step further. I would like to conclude by reminding President von der Leyen of her promise that she would treat legislative proposals from this House as if this House has the proper legislative right of initiative. So please, Ms von der Leyen, a follow-up to the report.

name: Nicolaus Fest
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Commission wants to link the disbursement of funds to the rule of law and democracy. This is, in principle, a good idea, if democracy and the rule of law were in good shape in the EU. Unfortunately, this is not the case. On the contrary, we have seen for years that the demand for the rule of law is used exclusively by instruments, namely when it is right.  A few examples: in Germany, judges of the Constitutional Court are appointed by politicians. That is fine – it is a scandal in Poland. The brutal attacks by police forces on yellow vests in France are not even mentioned in the report on the rule of law. Turkey has been an Islamist dictatorship for years. EU response: nothing. Negotiations continue with Turkey about their accession and continue to pay it billions.  For example, Africa: hardly any of the countries there meet our requirements under the rule of law. But it is precisely with Africa that the EU now wants to establish a new partnership, in other words to make rich, corrupt regimes even richer.  For example, Palestine: there too, we know, is one of the most corrupt regimes in the world. There, too, the EU is doing nothing, but is silent.  Like so much in the EU, the rule of law mechanism is a lie. It is not about the rule of law. It is a question of blackmailing other countries. Countries such as Poland, which oppose the nonsense of gender ideology, or countries such as Hungary, which do not want migration of criminals and social smugglers.  So the rule of law mechanism is a lie, and anyone who is with your senses will not agree with it.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Last week, the Commission presented a report on the rule of law, thank you very much! Article 7 procedures have been floundering for months; there are European semesters, there is a European Justice Scoreboard, there is a peer review in the Council, and tomorrow we will be voting on our report on a rule of law mechanism. Why? Quite simply, it's time for consolidation. It is not acceptable for all the institutions to confuse in such an important field. That is why, in our report, we call for coordinated monitoring from all three institutions. It is time for more independence and credibility. An honest stocktaking is only conceivable if experts are actively involved. We therefore call for a panel of experts to accompany this report. It is time for more real political ambition. Yes, the Commission's report is a step in the right direction and not a lie, Mr Fest. But hand on heart: did we send the Commissioners into the race last year and send them to the Commission to take stock of academics and work out think tank lists? No! Only if a Parliament is actually involved will this report become a truly effective story. And it's time to look at the whole thing. This whole also includes fundamental rights, fundamental rights and anti-discrimination, as stated in Article 2, and that is what we are calling for. That is what we have been elected for, and we will work it out. Vote tomorrow!

text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no and will not be consent to non-treaty action, there is no legal basis for this report. name: Nikolaj Villumsen
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam. President! Should we accept that a number of EU countries are violating fundamental principles of the rule of law and democratic rights? The answer is a resounding no! However, if we look at what has happened in Hungary under Orban, we look at what has happened in Poland with the current right-wing government, we look at developments in Bulgaria, then it is clear that the European Union has failed to defend human rights and democracy. If the European Union is to pride itself on being the guardian of democracy and human rights, fine words are not enough. Then action is needed. We need independent and continuous monitoring of respect for the democratic rules of the game and respect for human rights in the individual Member States. We need a clear consistency against governments that choose to violate citizens' rights. That is why the EU coffers must be slammed against Orban and anyone else who violates fundamental human rights and democracy. It is not just about guaranteeing the democratic rights of Hungarian and Polish citizens. It is about all citizens of the European Union deserving, respecting their human rights and their rule of law and noticing a consequence. That is not the case today and it needs to change.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the procedure laid down in Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union has proved inadequate to prevent, correct and sanction attacks and threats to the rule of law, democracy and respect for fundamental rights in the European Union. It is aware of this that, with the violations of the common values of the European Union, which are set out in Article 2 of the Treaty, it contributes to undermining citizens' rights and mutual trust between the Member States and to weakening the legal and political bases of the European project. In the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union for 2013 and 2014, for which I was rapporteur, as well as on other occasions, such as the in 't Veld report, this Parliament called for the establishment of a monitoring mechanism and systematic assessment, country by country, with recommendations and preventive and corrective measures, in order to ensure overall respect for the values on which the European Union is founded. In order to ensure democratic control and avoid any political and instrumental use of this mechanism, it must be based on objective criteria and must comply with the principles of transparency, impartiality and equality between Member States, especially in the case of sanctions procedures and budgetary conditionality procedures. Parameters such as the separation of powers, the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression and media pluralism, human rights and active and passive democratic participation in electoral processes, as well as problematic aspects such as the fight against corruption and all forms of discrimination, must remain cornerstones against any authoritarian, illiberal and anti-democratic tendencies that threaten the future of Europe and its citizens.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Europe is the result of the values that were broken before, during and after the war, the values on which the European Union was later founded: dignity, freedom, democracy, human rights; in short, rule of law and separation of powers. The values pre-EU.  It is not an obligation for Democrats to belong to the European Union; comply with the principles of the rule of law, yes. That is why there must be a neutral control mechanism in the European Union that warns us of the danger when the rule of law may be at risk somewhere, no matter whether that place is Romania, Hungary, Malta, Spain, the German Republic, France, anywhere. There must be an instrument to ensure that all Member States are measured by the same standard.  The mechanism proposed today does not serve to judge governments, we are not and do not want to be courts of justice. But it serves to put an end to this practice according to which the rule of law is more or less at risk depending on the color of the political party it has. When it comes to governments on the left, it seems to us on the right that the rule of law is at risk; when it comes to left-wing governments, it happens the other way around. This is not right-wing or left-wing, this is about defending the rule of law, because the rule of law is so important, too important to play politics with it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the history of the Union is the story of integration governed by law and based on values, but the history of this mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights begins in the Committee on Freedoms of this European Parliament. Once upon a time, there was the "Copenhagen dilemma", which is the distance between the Copenhagen criteria—the values enshrined in Article 2—and our ability to respond to those who aggressively offend them from within: these so-called "liberals". By the way, Commissioner Jourová, all solidarity in the face of unfair attacks directed against you to intimidate you. Those States pointed out in Article 7 complain: everything is sessed, everyone practices double standard. It is precisely the intention of the mechanism to examine all the Member States of the European Union on a regular, general and objective point. Commissioner Reynders presented it to the Committee on Freedoms on 30 September and we welcome it. Methodology and sources can be improved and refined. I would add now: this story will not end well until we establish by regulation conditionality on access to European funds and the European budget strictly linked to compliance with the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. If not, this story will have no happy ending.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: "Madam President, we are going through the storm here and we know that if we do not strengthen European democratic confidence, we will not be able to meet every social challenge or every economic challenge. We have never had a real mechanism on the table before to monitor the quality of Member States' democracies, and the first thing we have to remind ourselves of is what this rule of law is about. Well, it aims to avoid the arbitrariness of power over citizens, it has to do with rights and obligations being objective, and it has to do with dignity. This is what democracy is about, and every now and then, from time to time, we have to remember it, because the virus of populism, the virus of authoritarianism, of the chieftains, is there, always dormant. This is a time when we have to do this work and the Commission, even if Parliament wants more, will have a central role, at least for now, in the implementation of this mechanism. It is very important, as Mr González Pons has already said, that it becomes a logbook, that it is not politicized, that it is objective, because otherwise we will not be able to encourage some to improve their standards and others not to pass certain red lines. And we have to do this without blind spots, whether it's state entities or substats that jeopardize democracy, because populists promise bread, but it's bread for today and hunger for tomorrow.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Madam President, the European Union already has an economic tutelage over its Member States, but that is no longer enough for it, it now also wants to exercise ideological tutelage over them. The 'Eimeka' report is the instrument of this new federalist offensive. Personally, I strongly oppose it because I do not want my country to be treated like a child. I do not want it to be noted by pseudo-experts who will behave like political commissioners. I do not want them to oblige it to respect all the whims of the Union, such as the ideology of gender, the apologies of migrants, the omnipotence of judges or the hatred of the religious and cultural roots of our national identity. And I don't want them to impose the lead on political correctness, under the pretext of fighting fake news or misinformation. The Europe I dream of is the opposite of your model of Father Fouettard. I want a free Europe, proud of its many national identities and whose ambition would be to promote its civilization rather than to self-flagellate. I want a radiant Europe that would organise the resistance of its Member States in the face of the multiple external dangers and migratory submersion, instead of always providing the same soft answer that can be summed up in one word: submission.

name: Sylwia Spurek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Last week, a funeral was held in Poland for a child, a 12-year-old girl who committed suicide on the grounds of sexual orientation. For months, Polish politicians have been attacking LGBT+ people, violating their dignity, inciting hatred. The candidate for the new Minister of Education is a person who promotes homophobia. All this is happening in the Union in 2020.  At the previous session of Parliament, the President of the European Commission spoke beautifully about equality, dignity and respect, but these are just words. Eu funds continue to flow into the Polish government. And for twelve years now, the European Commission has been unable to pass an equality horizontal directive. Of course, we need a mechanism on the rule of law that covers the full range of Article 2 values, but if the Commission does not continue to exercise its powers, it will still be words, words, words.

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab You are attacking Poland, moreover, in a particularly brazen way, historically admonishing us with some totalitarianism. In the meantime, I want to tell you why you have this economic advantage today that allows you to be so arrogant Polish. Because, ladies and gentlemen, historically, as you say, when Poland was under attack by Germany and the Soviets, your countries stood and watched Poland honorably defend values, and then for poland defending these values, you gave Poland away to the Soviets and watched as it could not develop for decades. And that's why you have that economic advantage today and brazenly... I will tell you this: give us those years that Poland has lost, then none of you will allow this arrogance.  I'll tell you more: you're going to remind us today of LGBT-free zones. And you know that Poland was the only country where homosexuality was not criminalized? You could learn a lot from Poles, especially in terms of values, tolerance. Today Poland bothers you, because it is doing much better than you. Especially look at Spain, where almost every second young person does not have a job. From Polish you could learn it today, but it suffocates you, that's why you attack Poland.

name: Milan Uhrík (NI).
text: – Madam President, Mr Šimečka, I am sorry, but this cannot really be listened to anymore. You want to make the disbursement of money from the common European budget subject to compliance with some liberal EU rules. So states that are not independent courts, but you, brussels liberal politicians, decide that they are not obeying, they will only have to pay into the EU and they will get nothing out of it. Say it straight away that you want to punish Poles, Hungarians, Slovaks and everyone else because they do not want to accept immigrants. That they don't want to push the LGBT agenda, that they don't want to blindly obey foreign NGOs and liberal journalists, because that's really the point. We can never support something like this, because in Slovakia, in Central Europe, we already have experience of it, and in the past it was called totalitarianism. The people out there have nothing left to put in the pot, and you are blocking the approval of the European budget and the provision of aid with precisely such meaningless demands to strengthen your own dominance. That's something outrageous, really outrageous.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, Mr Šimečka, I would first like to greet you both for the reports you have been able to make. Frankly, I am very happy to know that we are finally taking steps to have a mechanism that applies to all States, a mechanism for monitoring the rule of law. But there is one point i would like to draw attention to: we are very focused, and well, on the idea that there can be no aid to states that do not comply with the rules of the rule of law. But there are European states that do not receive aid, and for them there must also be sanctions in case they do not comply with the rule of law. Because the values of the rule of law are not pecuniary values, they are fundamental values. As my colleague Bilčík and my colleague González Pons said here, these are fundamental values of Europe's identity, of the identity of democracies. And so we have to think of a mechanism that applies even to all States, and not only to those who are net-income states of EU funds, because there cannot be a mechanism for monitoring democratic values and the rule of law that applies only to the poorest states, to those in convergence. There must be a mechanism that can be valid for all states, from the richest and largest to the smallest and poorest.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it’s time for the EU to not only talk the talk but also walk the walk. The EU is built on the notion that we are stronger together and that fundamental rights and values must never be an issue up for compromise. I’m happy, therefore, that there is still an overwhelming majority here in this Parliament who stand up for those rights, even though there are a few extremists on that side who are trying to say otherwise. However, I am worried about the current developments at the same time. We see attacks on independent media, on LGBTQI people, we see attacks on women, we see attacks on migrants. We also see a politicisation of the independent judiciary. I welcome, of course, the new rule of law report presented last week, but we need to go further. This resolution suggests important, measurable goals, involvement of  civil society and a broader scope to also include fundamental rights and democracy. We must make sure that the EU does not remain a toothless tiger, because this report is good – but we must make sure to provide it with teeth. One of the best ways of providing the tiger with teeth is through stronger conditionality linked to the budget. Our values are, for sure, not up for compromise.

name: Anna Júlia Donáth (Renew).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Today, in Europe, some governments are destroying the rule of law, building an inhumane and unjust system. I am glad that Europe is finally determined, because we must now do something about it. We Members committed to a just rule of law have three demands. One, Europe must act forcefully against the rule of law and against leaders who build unjust regimes. Two, we need tools, mechanisms that cannot be played out directly by two governments that are covering for each other. Three, we always expect the peoples of the Member States concerned not to be punished for the crimes of their governments. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. The Hungarian people are telling you, European decision-makers, that the Hungarian people are not equal to Viktor Orban! Let us not fill the Prime Minister with European resources, but give them to those for whom we are essentially meant: decent people, businesses, NGOs! I've had enough helplessness! The future of Europe must be nothing more than a strong, just and active alliance.

name: Filip De Man (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we want to link certain rights of Member States to respect for democracy. That sounds noble, of course, but the secret agenda is this: those who do not bend to the progressive, globalist, multicultural agenda of the unelected Commissioners and Co will be caught. Poland, Hungary and other recalcitrant countries must be punished for not being in line.  Only there is a problem for the EU nomenklatoera. It does not have the means to punish the Member States. That is why an amendment to the Treaty of the Union is now being proposed, introducing a sanctions mechanism. Unanimous decisions would no longer be necessary. The countries that still have the courage to go against the Commission and co would be forced by this new dictatorship to give up their defences. In other words, those who oppose mass immigration, who do not go along with the gender madness, who, according to the Commission, makes a pluralistic press impossible, who supposedly threatens the independence of the judiciary, who will feel the revenge – the financial revenge of the Commission and co – itself.  This, ladies and gentlemen, is not the Europe of the sovereign nations we stand for, which the ID Group stands for. This is rather a de-ification EUSSR soft dictatorship.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the deeper our challenges, the more our values matter. Times of crisis can erode freedom and fairness. As we all know, no country is immune to this. Protecting human rights, promoting free speech and free media, passing legislation that increases freedom and does not discriminate, and ensuring court systems that do not allow political interference or bias – this is the only true path to stability and prosperity. The rule of law is not the enemy of great government – the belief that our values are extinguishable is! The rule of law was not designed to protect governments and elites, but to protect people. For those that seek to stray from our shared values, I hope they reach the conclusion that by respecting democracy and the rule of law, there is much to be gained and far less to lose.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: Mr President, is an EU mechanism, as proposed here, the solution? I'm afraid not.  Firstly, you need a clear objective measure by which we can measure or determine the situation in the various Member States, and there is no such thing now. And whether you can develop it at all is very much a question. The proposal will certainly lead to a lot of infighting and perhaps even to a hexit, a pexit or a spexit.  Secondly, such a mechanism will only work well if Member States embrace and endorse the method used. And if not, it will only result in more administrative junk at a high cost, without a goal being achieved. It's a waste of money and especially now.  In short, while respecting all good intentions and the great work of producing something that promotes a positive development of democracy and the rule of law, I ask all Members to throw this report to the dust off for the time being because it would do more harm than good. We are calling for a decentralised approach. Unfortunately, I don't have time to go into this in more detail.  Finally, I would like to point out that the EU itself is not very democratic. Let's do something about that first.

name: Kris Peeters (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, Ursula von der Leyen came to the heart of the matter in her State of the Union address and I quote: 'The rule of law protects people from the state of power.' It is difficult to underestimate the importance, because without independent judges and journalists there is no justice. Nevertheless, journalists are under increasing pressure and judges are becoming increasingly influenced.  Our response as the European Parliament must be clear, because the Article 7 procedures are deadlocked and the budget proposal to make EU funds dependent on respect for the rule of law is being watered down every week. We therefore call for a structural and objective evaluation of the rule of law with tangible consequences for offenders. As long as we do not untangle this knot, all discussions about respect for the rule of law will sound hollow.

name: Klára Dobrev (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Who are we fighting for, many people ask me when we demand the rule of law. My answer is that the rule of law protects ordinary people when the state abuses its power, when the authorities, the courts, do not bring them to justice. When we fight for the rule of law, we fight for ordinary people. When we fight for the rule of law, we are fighting for taxpayers who have the right to know whether state leaders are using public money for themselves, for the enrichment of their families, or for the benefit of the country. The institutions of the rule of law serve to make sure that no government can wipe out taxpayers' money. When we fight for the rule of law, we fight for taxpayers. Viktor Orban is against the rule of law because he wants to continue to use the support of the European Union to enrich his family members and oligarchs. However, we want these billions to be in the interest of the Hungarian people, Hungary, and therefore we insist that European aid be conditional on the rule of law.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Madam President, I hear many words which for me are just words, because I have actually experienced what some people are saying here about fascism and racism, I have experienced it. Seven years ago I went to prison illegally, with the personal intervention of the then Prime Minister of Greece, Antonis Samaras. The audio document exists, it was heard inside the Greek Parliament. The country's prime minister was speaking to a supreme court justice named Doyakos and telling him that the next day three current MPs would be remanded in custody. Their crime was that they were talking about Greece, they were talking about Christianity, at a time when we are all talking about the new order of things and illegal illegal immigration. This was the price we paid to some who had put my country in the vise of the memorandums, had flattened and sold out Greece.  This audio documentary has been and has not dared anyone in the Greek Parliament to react. Indeed, after a few months, while all these politicians buried it, a request came from the prosecutors of my country, who were asking for the case to be examined and for the then Prime Minister to be prosecuted, which was not the case, as he was covered by the whole political spectrum. I have previously heard the representative of the European People's Party speak and say nice words about democracy when in his own party is this political bum, the then Prime Minister, who was not prosecuted because he was covered by the grown-ups who cover for him. This is the democracy that the European Union wants to implement against those who oppose and tell the truth. I would like to inform you that, after seven years of persecution that I have suffered and after all the consequences, I will not back down and continue to talk about my country and About Christianity in Europe.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Shimeka on his report. The rule of law is one of the founding values of the European Union. It is therefore important to have coherence between the European institutions on these issues.  Upholding the rule of law, around which we are unconditionally united all in the European Parliament, also means preventing any form of double standard vis-à-vis individual Member States. I would like to point out that the first annual report is a proper step in this direction. The new non-discriminatory mechanism, which was presented by the European Commission, put all countries in the European Union on an equal footing, assessing them on the same and objective criteria and making recommendations to support the efforts being made at national level. In discussing the last meeting of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Commissioner Reynders stated the commitment to work towards a true culture of the rule of law. Another such initiative is also linking the allocation of European Union funds to adherence to the rule of law by Member States, which the European People's Party supported last year. I believe that this must necessarily lie within the European Union's toolbox in defence of the rule of law and democratic values.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this fruitful discussion which shows the urgency of the topic. I think that developments in the EU in the last decades show that we had undermined something, that we believe that the rule of law principle, democracy, fundamental rights, all these universal – not left and right – but universal European values will last forever, that they do not need any kind of effort or any kind of protection. We were mistaken. That’s why now we are trying to enlarge our toolbox and enlarge our possibilities to address the problems we see in the Member States and to tackle the problems together with the Member States. It is the meaning and purpose of the rule of law report which we presented last week. We needed to have a new preventive tool which we will create in the report, we will develop it in an inclusive manner, using transparent methodology which will invite us for the dialogue with the Member States, and I believe in dialogue, even with the Member States where we seem not to have very welcoming reactions. We also needed to come with a conditionality relating to EU money. We are going to distribute EUR 1.7 trillion in the next years for a very good reason: the European Union has to use the money for the best purpose to help European citizens to get out of this crisis and to develop new qualities and to open the chance for development in promising areas. But it cannot work to distribute such a big amount of money while we are in the atmosphere of decreasing trust. It cannot work. That’s why we want to achieve this conditionality to be introduced in our system. The Commission will work also, as I said to you, on the strategy on the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Democracy Action Plan. You’re calling for covering the whole scope, which we see also in Mr Šimečka’s report, which I heard many times from Sophie in’t Veld and other Members of Parliament. The Commission is addressing all three, but uses three different, if I may say, vehicles or methods. In the European Democracy Action Plan, we want to come up with efficient measures on how to protect free and fair elections because whatever positives we do to protect democracy and the rule of law in the Member States, the first and the last word is for the citizens living in the Member States. That’s why I think we should do more to protect their right to cast their free vote and that’s why in the action plan, we will focus on protecting the system where there is a level playing field for campaigning and financing of the political parties and political campaigns. We would like to have guaranteed fairer judiciary oversight over the elections and, last but not least, access to objective information, so we will focus on the freedom of speech and pluralistic media, which will deliver objective information. I think that we have to continue our work. It’s quite obvious also from today’s debate that there is a very demanding job for all three institutions, be it the Commission, Parliament, or the Council. We have to find a way to continue the work and not rely on the naivety from the past that our rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights are some kind of perpetual pillar which will last forever.  (Applause)

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank Members for the very broad support that has been given to the defence of common values. This is important because these common values allow us to develop a climate of trust within the European Union and to make it work in all its aspects, such as cooperation between the courts but also the internal market and many other elements of relations between citizens. I would like to go back to a few points on the annual report on the rule of law, which is part of that mechanism. I would like to remind you first of all that this report by the Commission, the guardian of the treaties, presents the 27 Member States of the Union on an equal footing. This report does not contain recommendations in the formal sense of the word, but clear assessments, which will enable the Commission and any other institution to continue monitoring in future editions. Secondly, the Commission will continue to use all the tools at its disposal, the report, infringement procedures, or Article 7 procedures, which are currently under way before the Council in order to provide an effective and proportionate response to any breach of the rule of law. The Commission is ready to participate in the implementation of additional tools, including an effective tool to protect the European budget, in line with respect for the rule of law. I would also like to point out that the Commission is committed, on the rule of law, to an inter-institutional dialogue which a number of members of this House have called for. And we look forward to continuing to talk to you and the Council not only about the first report but also about the mechanisms to be put in place in the future.  I would therefore like to reiterate once again that it is indeed a Commission report before you, but there will of course be nothing to prevent Parliament from involving experts in its own work and debates. And we also count on your support, ladies and gentlemen, to engage in dialogue with national parliaments. This will be an important opportunity to debate not only here in the Council, as the German Presidency has already scheduled the debate meetings on the report and on a number of Member States, but also in the European Parliament and in national parliaments. And I would remind you, as I said in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, that if you also want to address reports by Member State in Parliament, the Commission is at your disposal. And then, of course, the report deals with the Member States, but in order to be able to talk about the rule of law and respect for fundamental values with neighbours, candidates, partners, including in Africa or elsewhere in the world, we must first also think about doing the work at home. That is what a whole range of procedures we use are for, that is what the annual report will serve, which will open up an ongoing debate on the rule of law within the European Union, and it is an important condition to be credible when we defend common values that are dear to us, even outside the European Union.

name: Michal Šimečka
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone who took part in this debate and, specifically, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have worked on this file and made it a better text. They were all very constructive and helped produce a report which, I hope, will gain a broad majority in the vote tomorrow. Let me also very briefly respond to some of the critical comments and, specifically, to Mr Fest, who is somehow suggesting that this is a disingenuous exercise because we don’t criticise Turkey or some African Republics. Obviously, I would love it if Turkey and countries in our neighbourhood subscribed to the same rule of law mechanism and conditionality that we have here, but that’s not possible. I think that, precisely to have credibility externally, we need to do this at home, to make sure that our Member States subscribe to the values and principles of the EU. To Ms Kempa, who is suggesting that somehow I don’t like Poland or I am being manipulated, first of all, this is nothing against Poland. Being a Slovak, obviously I consider Poles to be my brotherly nation. The problem is with the current Polish Government, and it’s not just me saying that, it’s the European Commission, the European Court of Justice, the Council of Europe and all sorts of other organisations. So there’s no conspiracy against Poland. Finally, I would like to thank both Vice—President Jourová and Commissioner Reynders for their commitment to the rule of law report presented today, which indeed is a historic step forward that must be acknowledged. The issue that we have and the proposal that we are putting forward is to make it stronger and to make a clear link with enforcement and further action. It is obviously to enlarge the scope, but also to put it on solid legal grounds through an interinstitutional agreement, which the Parliament can propose, because there might be Commissioners after you who will not have the same kind of commitment. There might be a Presidency after which will not have the same kind of commitment. So we want to have something that is solid and which all three institutions can have joint ownership of. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Tuesday, 6 October 2020 and the final vote on Wednesday, 7 October 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D)
text: Writing. – The rule of law is the foundation of true democracy, especially if we do not want the rights of the weaker to be trampled on by the stronger ones. However, in order for this to work, respect for the principles of democracy, including the rule of law and respect for human rights, must also be objectively assessed and punished in the event of serious violations. I therefore welcome all initiatives calling for the establishment of a fair mechanism for the regular evaluation of this area in all EU countries in the same way. A few days ago, the European Commission published its first assessment of the state of the rule of law, giving Poland and Hungary the worst mark. However, the government in Budapest subsequently described the report as unfair, based mainly on information from so-called 'Soros' organisations. It is all the more important that any new monitoring mechanism produces only absolutely objective reports. Today, however, there is talk of making the absorption of European money by the Member States conditional on respect for the rule of law. As a last of all, this means suspending funds for the state government, which does not comply with these principles. I am not opposed to the fact that the European Commission's new monitoring tool contains a well-defined mechanism for how the money allocated to a given state will reach its eligible beneficiaries without going through government instruments. In fact, the people and businesses of states whose governments receive a negative assessment cannot be held hostage by their governments and lose money from the EU budget to which they contribute through their taxes.

name: Julie Lechanteux (ID)
text: In writing. The creation of a union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is the centrepiece of punitive legislation, which aims to muzzle governments that oppose the globalist, authoritarian and illiberal drift of the European Union. This report follows the "New Pact on Migration and Asylum" of 23 September and the "State of Law Report 2020" presented on 30 September: a triptych intended to punish defenders of national sovereignty and all those who refuse the indiscriminate opening of borders to illegal migration flows.  In the line of sight of this new punitive legislation is Hungary and its Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who dared to defend his country's interests against the political interference of mercenary NGOs and close its borders to the flood of migrants. The latest episode is the assertions of the European Commissioner for Values and Transparency, Vera Jourova, who has called Hungary a 'sick democracy', an intolerable value judgment by a senior EUROPEAN official who is supposed to be working in the interests, not against, the 27 Member States.

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques (S&D)
text: in writing. – Democracy, the rule of law, fundamental rights, respect for minorities and their protection are fundamental values of the EU. We have seen some of these principles violated by Member States. The ability of the European institutions to act in cases where these values do not seem to be respected must be ensured. Therefore, a rule of law mechanism is urgent; not one more, but from a complementary perspective with other instruments. The RULE of Law report in the EU, now presented by the European Commission, is an initiative that deserves support. It is good that corruption and freedom of the press are elements to be scrutinised in the context of this regular report. But it's not enough. Democracy, fundamental rights, freedom of association, or the protection of more vulnerable groups must also be scrutinised. This monitoring mechanism, objective and based on concrete data, should ensure the monitoring of these principles in all EU Member States. This strategy should be based on interinstitutional cooperation, a transparent and regular process, so that the promotion of EU values becomes effective and has visibility into the European agenda. Addressing the crisis of values in the EU is also a precondition for restoring mutual trust between Member States.

name: Beata Mazurek (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Why should this debate be used? Once again, the European Parliament is attacking Poland on the basis of fake news and highly perverted information given by the Polish opposition, the aim of which is not the good of the country, but the fight against the Polish government elected in democratic elections. Are there no serious problems in this day and age that we need to look at? What about the coronavirus pandemic, in which the spectre of the second wave peeks into our eyes? What about a wooing economy? What about rising unemployment? I will not mention the migration crisis anymore, because it is another subject that Europe is not coping with. Don't we really have more serious problems on our minds?  Or is this debate a kind of escape and a substitute topic for problems that we cannot find a solution to? You took Poland and Hungary in the crosshairs. You do not seem to notice that the judicial systems or the media in Poland function as they do in western European countries. There is no and will not be our consent to take decisions that strike at Poland by officials who, by posting, not by democratic choice, will decide on matters that are only the domain of the Member States, while using the 'whip of the rule of law' used, as history has already shown, selectively. We do not have our permission to do so.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union already provides for mechanisms and procedures to protect the fundamental values of the Union, such as the sanctioning procedures provided for in Article 7 or infringement procedures. Along the way, the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism and the inclusion of the justice chapter in the reports for the European Semester were added. However, the debate on the effectiveness of the instruments available to the EU continues.  A very important step was the Commission's proposal in July 2019 to verify the soundness of the rule of law in all Member States, and the first report was carried out on 30 September 2020. However, this singular approach must be institutionalised and permanentised.  In this context, I support Parliament's proposal to establish, together with the European Council and the European Commission, the European Mechanism on Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights (DSF). In essence, we propose an annual monitoring of compliance with the EU's fundamental values in all Member States.  The monitoring will consist of three stages: preparatory - in which all the necessary information is gathered, the publication of the annual report, with country-specific recommendations and the debate on the content of the Commission's report by the European Council and the European Parliament. The conclusions of the report will form the basis of the decision to initiate or not the Article 7 procedure or the infringement proceedings.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Is the European Union afraid of freedom? It's starting to look like a lot. When we talk about undermining democracy, the rule of law and the fundamental values of the EU, we euphemistically refer to 'illiberal democracies' and 'autocracies'. We do not dare to say out loud that there are Member States that are no longer democracy and are ruled by dictators. Human Rights Watch said recently: "Ten million Europeans live under authoritarian rule." Ten million. In the EU.  The tools at our disposal to protect the basic values of Article 2 VEU are not adequate. We are now working on solutions, but once again the Commission and the Council are putting the brakes on. In the Council's proposed mechanism to link the multiannual budget to respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, we only check whether Member States are not harming the EU's financial interests. That didn't help a judge, no journalist, and no LGBTI citizen. And the newly launched monitoring system for the rule of law does not monitor democracy and fundamental rights. If the Council continues to bow to one dictator, others will follow. That is why the question is: is the European Union afraid of freedom?

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on Rule of Law conditionality in the framework of the MFF 2021-2027 and Next Generation EU (2020/2797(RSP)). I should like to inform Members that for all debates of this part—session there will be no catch—the—eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank the commissionerfor the way in which we have been a member of parliament. I thank you all from the heart for once again having the opportunity to take part in such an important debate. However, I am somewhat stunned that Members dare to equate the European Union with a communist dictatorship.  Many of us represent states in which people have had to live their lives, have been persecuted and discriminated against precisely because they have stood up for these European values: freedom, democracy, the rule of law, an independent judiciary, respectful treatment of minorities – of whatever kind. When I met LGBTI activists from Poland last week, Mrs Kempa, I made it clear once again that this is not about special rights. It is about equal rights. Nobody expects special rights for minorities. But minorities are right to be treated in the same way as those who feel part of the majority society. Yes, who would have thought decades ago that we would end up in a situation where we are no longer sure of what holds us together at the heart of the European Union. After all, we are not primarily an internal market or a monetary community, we are above all and first and foremost a community of values and a community of law. Last but not least, the decisions of the European Court of Justice in relation to the decisions of some Member States have made it clear that there are quite objective shortcomings that need to be rectified. I would like to make this clear once again for the German Presidency of the Council of the EU: all Member States should be treated equally. It is not a question of pointing the finger at a few. That is why I see this debate – including the debate we have just had – as a tailwind for our debate, which is admittedly painful, tedious and highly controversial. After lengthy discussions, the German PRESIDENCY of the Council of the EU has put forward a proposal, building on the decision of the European Heads of State or Government. I can well understand, honourable Members, that one or the other is dissatisfied. If I were here as a representative of the German Government, I could even join in this dissatisfaction. However, I stand here as a representative of the Council. I represent the Council. And not even the proposal we have put forward has received the support of all the member states' delegations. This is our offer for negotiations with you. I can only appeal to everyone to reach a substantial result as soon as possible. I can assure you once again, and I hope you trust me, not me as a person, but you trust the German Presidency of the Council of the Eu and you trust what the Chancellor said to the European Parliament in her speech here: strengthening the rule of law is high on the agenda of what we have set out with you and with the Commission. I would ask you to respect the fact that conditionality on the rule of law is only a building block.  Following the commission's intensive report on the rule of law situation in Poland and Hungary at the last Council meeting under the Article 7 procedure, the German EU Presidency will continue the Article 7 procedures because, from the Commission's point of view, the serious concerns have not yet been fully addressed. In other words, we will look again– presumably in the form of hearings, at the situation of the rule of law in these two states. We are very grateful to the European Commission for presenting, for the first time ever in the history of a united Europe, a report on the rule of law, which concerns all Member States and which, incidentally, also contains some critical comments for my own country. We will deal with this report twice, because we all know that we lack, above all, a common understanding of what we are up to. The rule of law no longer unites us – and this is a bitter, sad finding – and the rule of law divides us. And that weakens us even in a world where democracy has come under pressure and authoritarianism is growing. That is why we must see that we hold this shop together. But there can be no political rebates when it is in question. Conditionality of the rule of law is now the new element.  Yes, we have made a proposal that cannot and must not ignore what the Heads of State or Government have agreed on. But I would like to reiterate to all those who are worried about the is also a working tool, shout: yes, that is it, because it is about breaking the rule of law. Already in the 2018 proposal there was a concrete reference to the EU budget. We have not come up with this again. I would also like to make it clear once again that the reference to the European Council does not entail a veto instrument for the European Council, but it has been the proposal to refer the matter to the European Council once again, if a Member State so wishes, in order perhaps to achieve once again the necessary level of common ground that we need. But there are two legislative bodies: this is Parliament, and that is the Council, and that is not the European Council. That is why it is not a veto for the European Council. It is just another way of getting rid of Gravamina as part of the dialogue.  In this respect, I would ask you all to play your part in ensuring that, within the framework of this very complicated and complex issue – 'Next Generation EU', MFF, climate mainstreaming, gender mainstreaming, own resources decision – we also create a regulation that makes it clear what we in the European Union are all about, namely the rule of law. When someone asks what this is all about, the very points that were also the basis for the report by the European Commission are also outlined, namely the independence of the judiciary, issues of checks and balances, media pluralism and media pluralism, and also an effective fight against corruption in all EU Member States. In this respect, Mr Lagodinsky, there is nothing wrong with the Council, and Mr Villumsen is also wrong. No one puts their hands in their lap. We are as close to a solution as we have been for a long time. But for that we need a constructive spirit of willingness to compromise and cooperation in all the EU institutions. That is what I ask you to do from the heart.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking you for the invitation to debate today the conditionality of respect for the rule of law, in the context of the multi-year financial framework. In this regard, I would also like to thank the German Presidency for the inclusion on the agenda of each meeting of the General Affairs Council on this issue of the rule of law by the end of the year. In her speech to the European Parliament on 16 September, President Ursula von der Leyen reiterated that the Commission attaches the utmost importance to respect for the rule of law. The European project is based on respect for this rule of law in all Member States. This is perhaps the most essential question in defining who we are in Europe. This is not only a moral imperative, but also a prerequisite for respect for democracy and fundamental rights, the proper functioning of the internal market, the correct application of European law, mutual trust and the maintenance of an investment-friendly environment.  It is our common duty to defend the rule of law in all Member States, because citizens expect their rights to be protected with this rule of law as a cornerstone of the protection we owe them. Ladies and gentlemen, in 2018 the Commission proposed a regulation to protect the EU budget against rule-of-law deficiencies. I thank the Parliament for its strong support for this proposal. The agreement of the July European Council on the Multiannual Financial Framework and Next Generation EU has created important expectations across Europe. The COVID-19 crisis presents an unprecedented challenge to all of us. The lives of millions of people, the future of hundreds of thousands of companies and the prospects of many regions depend on our recovery plan. Once adopted, this will be the largest package ever financed through the EU budget - a total of EUR 1.8 trillion. This makes it even more important that an agreement on the MFF and Next Generation EU is accompanied by a full set of measures to protect the EU budget. The Commission will continue to ensure that the EU budget is spent in line with applicable rules and principles. And so, every project financed by the EU budget will generate added value. In addition, the Commission fully agrees with the Parliament's request on the need to ensure the protection of final recipients and beneficiaries, and the Commission is committed to addressing this and other issues in all trilogues. The European Council's conclusions on the next MFF and Next Generation EU contain a clear commitment to the rule of law and to the protection of the financial interests of the Union. The Council Presidency has now a mandate for negotiations with the Parliament on the Commission proposal. The Commission has always said that it's ready to work with the co-legislators to improve the proposal on the table. I want to insist that we hope that the trilogue will now allow for a rapid adoption and for setting up an effective mechanism. And I insist on that: it must be effective, for European recovery and resilience will mean little if we get lost along the way. So we'll be very strong on such common defense of the values. Ladies and gentlemen, I am obviously counting on the strong support of the European Parliament to reach an agreement and quickly put in place the new generation of programme. Protecting our budget is in everyone's interest and we will obviously hear your comments and comments very carefully. My colleague, Commissioner Hahn, is here to respond to these questions or comments that you have made.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the German Presidency and Mr Roth for his statement and willingness to enter the negotiations. But let me also right away remind us all why we constantly return to this pressing matter in this House – and now, finally, we are going to address it together – and it’s this: our civil liberties are under excessive pressure.  Attacks on freedom of the press, civil society and judicial independence are seemingly becoming the standard in some Member States. Press freedom and the independence of the judiciary should not be privileges for the few; they are the fundamentals for free and functioning democracies. We just cannot allow the values enshrined in our Treaties to be systematically threatened or violated by any – and I underline by any – of the Member States while EU funds continue to be reserved by the responsible governments.  The citizens and taxpayers of Europe deserve a properly functioning conditionality mechanism on the rule of law, linked to the budget. The clock is ticking, and now we have to deliver, but a mechanism that cannot ever be triggered in practice due to back doors or indecisive processes serves only the interests of those who do not wish to see any measures taken.  So we urge the Council to join Parliament’s efforts to uphold democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Europe and hope really for constructive negotiations. We simply have to do everything we can in these negotiations.  (Applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Jacques Delors said in 2000 that the Union is doing well when the institutional triangle works and progress can be made with democratic responsibility and with the support of citizens. But if the Council blocks on fundamental issues and the Commission finally weakens, the Union resents it. That is why we must as soon as possible solve a fundamental problem, such as respect for the rule of law, because other hand, we will not be able to move forward. My group has long asked for a mechanism of respect for the rule of law, linked to the budget. We finally have a proposal on the table, but it's still insufficient, because it's not just about tacking corruption—we take that for granted, it would be more lacking. The rule of law goes much further: it is a common constitutional heritage that requires those who aspire to enter the European Union and assumes those of us who are already members.
