Article 2 of the Treaty says: the Union is based on values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights; pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between men and women. This is at the heart of the European project , let us not forget – much more important than the market. The role of the European Commission is to ensure compliance with the Treaties and, therefore, their assessment must be objective and, in order to strengthen their capacity, it would be good to be able to set up a specialised advisory panel. A strong Commission is essential for the proper functioning of the Union, it cannot be alibied by the Council's blockades. If a Member State makes a deaf ear to the European Commission and the European Commission sends its observations to the Council, the Council cannot be maniated by a qualified majority. Similarly, the Council must understand that European democracy gives the role of supervision to this House, to the European Parliament. Let's get it right and avoid blackmail and haggling. Europe doesn't deserve it. Someone should be interested in talking about a supposed struggle between democratic quality and economic recovery. I want both. That's why I ask you for responsibility and not to feed the divisions. We all have to be very careful with respect for our democracies, because, with the rise of populismos, the risk spreads across our countries, and because no one here is nobody's police nor can they look over the neighbor's shoulder. Democracy is conquered every day. You can never take it for granted. And that is why it is also important that this message reaches citizenship— which aims to help — and that is why we have insisted so much that the final recipients of the funds are not harmed. I have heard in this House use twisted arguments to say that we are against Hungary and Poland. Nothing further from reality. What we want is to defend the men and women of the European Union no matter where they live, what they believe, from whom they love, because that is the rule of law. Let's not go overboard now. Our principles are the backbone of the Union and the budget is the muscle we need to move and to move forward. Let's not give up any of them.

name: Moritz Körner
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her freedom of the press, which is restricted. Minorities who are disadvantaged. Money that goes into corrupt hands. All this is now taking place in Europe, and it must now be brought to an end, because it is even partly made possible with money from the EU, because we are still playing into the hands of these autocrats with some of the money. This must now be stopped. And if we now look at what – with all due respect, Minister of State Roth – the Council has now put on the table, that is no longer a mechanism of the rule of law. This is no longer a general attack on the rule of law, but only very specific violations. This is not really a rule of law mechanism, it is a pseudo-rule of law mechanism. And this pseudo-rule mechanism, which also runs the risk of never being triggered, because you have taken out the reverse qualified majority. Minister of State Roth, you have just explained in detail why the Council came to this position and why we must now find a common position as quickly as possible. But I say quite clearly here – and I believe, for many colleagues, that we will not simply change our position and nod off the Council's position. I can promise you that. You have now come a little way on Orban, and you can see what is doing Orban now? It goes one step further. We must have finally learned this lesson. He is playing with us and he is now saying that he is blocking the budget and the reconstruction fund. So he says that he certainly does not want to take more money now, because he may be able to retain less money or money afterwards through the rule of law mechanism. It's like shooting yourself in the knee as a precaution because of the fear of being attacked. And we have to uncover this game; it's a card game, and we need to uncover that bluff. To do this, we must remain tough as the European Parliament, and we as the European Parliament will remain tough on that. This is a red line for this European Parliament. We will no longer allow discounts on the rule of law.

name: Jérôme Rivière
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, rule of law, rule of law, with these terms for years, you have been attacking Hungary and Poland for refusing to submit to your federalist vision, a vision which makes the promotion of immigration a key issue of the European Union. Ms. Johansson reminded us last week.  But does the Commission and the majority of the European Parliament respect these obvious principles? No, and I'm going to show you that right away. Your political opponents do not have effective access to a judge, a right enshrined in Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights. Yes, in 2017, Ms Le Pen filed a complaint for forgery and use of forgery, with the constitution of a civil party in the hands of an investigating judge, against three persons: Mr Kessler, then Director General of OLAF, Mrs Redrado, Director of OLAF and Mr. Welle, who is still the Secretary-General of our Parliamentary Assembly.  This complaint denounces forgeries and use of forgeries committed by these three persons in the course of their duties and particularly in the context of an investigation by OLAF against Ms Le Pen, concerning her European parliamentary assistants. However, the investigating judge in Brussels has repeatedly asked the king's prosecutor to lift the parliamentary immunity of the three.  To date, more than three years later, what is the European Parliament's attitude to this request? The institutions of the European Union are not listening. Where is the respect for this rule of law invoked at every turn? Mr. Roth, where is the independent justice that you mentioned earlier? However, the speed of the parliamentary majority is known when it comes to lifting the immunity of members of the opposition, most often for alleged crimes of opinion or because of acts that are part of their political activities.  Your indignations are at the head of the client. The rule of law, as it must be applied, is first and foremost respect for the democratic choice of peoples. The Hungarian and Polish governments regularly triumph in the polls. Let us respect the decisions of Hungarians and Poles alike. Let's end the threats with this conditionality device.  The rule of law is also the same justice for all, majority as opposition. Finally, respect the requests of an investigating judge (inaudible words) who gives the impression that these institutions are tempted by a totalitarian drift, far removed from the rule of law.

name: Daniel Freund
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Mr Roth, I would like to thank Mr Roth for the work he has The proposal you made on the rule of law in the EU raises the hurdle so high that we all know that in practice there will never be a sanction. If there is no longer any independent media in a Member State, as is already the case in Hungary, then it should not be possible to sanction it. If, in one Member State, the government throws out all its unwelcome judges, as the Polish Government likes to imagine, then the Commission would first have to prove where it costs EU taxpayers money before we can sanction them. This has nothing to do with the protection of the rule of law. Nor is this a compromise between what the European Parliament decided here a year and a half ago and your position in the Council. What you have presented is another buckling in front of the dictator in Budapest. This must finally stop! We need this functioning, truly functioning, rule of law mechanism, in an emergency against Hungary and Poland.  The bluff that they now want to sabotage all the Corona aid for the whole of the European Union will dissipate when you finally fight with us in the European Parliament for the rule of law in Europe.

name: Bogdan Rzońca
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioners, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Union's multiannual financial framework, the reconstruction instrument and the Union's own resources are the main strength of the community's struggle for a better future. We are aware of this. In July this year, representatives of the 27 countries agreed and built international solidarity against the pandemic – much-needed solidarity.  Unfortunately, this positive image of the European Union is being tinged with an unfair discussion about the alleged lack of rule of law in Poland and Hungary. Moreover, instead of European solidarity, the European Commission wants to divide countries for better and worse by proposing non-treaty rules on linking funds to the rule of law. The European Commission does so without legal basis. Unfortunately, the European Commission is also violating a Member State's right to defend its reputation. The European Commission is mirroring Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, while also marginalising the European Council. We cannot talk about the rule of law in the language that Mrs Barley speaks, we cannot say that certain countries, such as Poland and Hungary, must be starved. I invite Mrs Barley to Polish – we will show her those places where she was starved, where totalitarian systems – communist and Nazi – caused people, children to be starved and the hearth alive. This is not the case in Poland and Hungary.  Let's not speak this language, it's a very bad language, it interferes with the agreement. Let us return – and here I ask the Commissioners – to work on the real principles and resources of our own and the Budget of the European Union, because it is needed in the fight against the pandemic and the European crisis.

name: Silvia Modig
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the rule of law is at the heart of Europe's values. If we cannot rely on the legality of our societies, the bottom will crumble from everything. Some Member States have seen such worrying developments and repeatedly that we cannot move forward together until we have a mechanism that works. At the moment, EU money is used to support those in power who do not respect and do not intend, and do not want to respect the rule of law. The wording of the presidency's proposal is so weak and the way in which it is decided that this proposal does not provide any certainty that this will create a mechanism capable of effectively addressing activities that threaten or combat the rule of law.  It is quite clear that if the judiciary is neither free nor independent, such a country will not have a credible way of investigating possible misuses of funds. This in itself creates such a risk to the budget that it should be sufficient. It should automatically trigger the measures, but this is not the case in the mandate presented. There is quite a burden of proof on the Commission to point out the misuse of the budget before sanctions are imposed. Decision-making should be a relative majority. The majority should oppose sanctions separately. If action requires a majority vote, it is very unlikely that any sanctions will ever be imposed on anyone. But, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not just about securing the budget, but the rule of law also protects a free civil society, democracy, the free media, free elections, minorities and freedom of expression. A functioning rule of law guarantees the fundamental rights of a free society and its members and, if implemented, requires respect for legality. That is why we need an effective, binding mechanism and I appeal to the Presidency-in-Office of the Council to raise your ambitions.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Madam President, evaluating the rule of law is difficult so let’s trust objective criteria. The UN report on arbitrary detention has complaints regarding political prisoners in 42 states. Only one, only one, is an EU Member State. Guess who? Hungary? Poland? No! Spain. One of the prisoners, Mr Junqueras, is an elected Member of this Parliament. So all democrats recognise that holding political prisoners is incompatible with the rule of law. However, the Commissioners writing their report about the rule of law in Spain have totally disregarded this fact. It’s not even mentioned! How can you want to have credibility when you speak about the rule of law when you write these kind of reports? This report about Spain is a shame. Last week, the Supreme Court of Spain dismissed the President of Catalonia. The votes of Catalans are not valid to elect MEPs or to elect presidents. How can you have some respect for these reports? Please act before it’s too late.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, three years ago, the citizens of my home country, Romania, went to the streets to defend the rule of law, the fight against (inaudible passage), a strong and independent judiciary, in the cold in the winter, in the heat in the summer. They did that with the European flag in their hands, and I can tell you that was one of my proudest moments as a Romanian citizen and as a European citizen. The people in the streets were asking for a strong role of the European Union in defence of European values. Colleagues, I turn to you tonight: now is the time to answer the call of the people of Europe, who expect us to stand up for European values. Why now? Because we are about to adopt the budget of the European Union for the next seven years and we are going to add on top – rightly so – a EUR 750 billion EU recovery mechanism. We’re going to spend more money than ever, and the more money we spend, the better the control of it needs to be. Now is the time to invent a clear rule of law mechanism linked to European funds. How should it be? It should be clear. It should be objective. It should treat all countries fairly and it should treat all Member States equally. It should not be political. It should be effective. It should not be watered down. This is what we call for. There is a clear majority in favour of it in the European Parliament. Mr Roth, let’s start negotiations on this without any further delays. We have had a position on it for one and a half years, and let’s deliver now.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that here we are all aware of the importance of this debate, because we speak, nothing more and nothing less, than the rule of law; but also the importance it has in its relationship with the three dossiers that will surely be the three most important dossiers for the coming years: financial framework, own resources and recovery plan. And we are all also aware of the need, of the urgency of reaching an agreement as soon as possible so that programs can start without delay. But time is not the most important thing, because we have a responsibility to negotiate an impeccable mechanism from a democratic point of view and, of course, effective, setting clear criteria and without wrong objective.  And I have said this on several occasions: the most positive thing is that we finally have a proposal from the Council on which we can sit and negotiate. There are positive aspects in that position and I would like to highlight the inclusion of this recovery plan in that regulation. It is something that most groups support here, but which we obviously do not include in our position because we negotiated it two years ago. But there are also points in that position which concern me quite a bit: that the definition of a rule of law should be reduced to the minimum, when we should be just as demanding with the States that are now members of the Union as we were at the time, when they wanted to join the Union, or as we are being with the candidates, I think it was a mistake. Of course, I am concerned that they will change the reverse qualified majority by a qualified majority, or that they have barely given a sentence to protecting the final beneficiaries, because, I repeat this, we do not have to be wrong about what is decided in the Council, and that they give the European Parliament almost a mere advisory role or, at most, validation of what is decided in the Council , because this is already starting to be worrying.  Anyway, we have a lot to discuss, but at least we have that proposal to start negotiating with.

name: Valérie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last week Viktor Orbon called for the resignation of Commissioner Jourova, who is responsible for upholding our values. Reaction from other states: nothing! We note, but above all we are not offended. And today, the same Viktor Orban threatens to block the recovery plan. Why would you do that? Because Europeans refuse to allow democracies, their democracy to be de-cluttered, with the help of their taxes.  Frankly, how did we get to this point? Perhaps if states were no longer sclerotic by unanimity then we could finally protect our democracies. Perhaps if the States were no longer sclerotic by unanimity, we could start the recovery quickly without some shouting gold when we talk about solidarity. Minister, negotiations on the next budget are deadlocked. In your house, everyone has submitted their veto threat, now we will have to unravel all this. So let's move on! We're ready! 2021 is three months away!

name: Peter Kofod (ID).
text: Madam President! We must take good care of taxpayers' money, which is why, of course, I support the fact that we are having a discussion about what demands you as a country must meet in order to gain access to the EU's staggering many billions. But let me just say two things in this regard: firstly, it pains me to see that countries such as my own have to pay much more for an EU project which, against my party's recommendation years ago, let a group of countries into the European Union on the back of some very naïve ideas and where democracies are fragile. And our Danish tax dollars are pouring away! The European Union founded a mistake many years ago, and now there is a problem with these countries being major beneficiaries of EU aid. If it was up to me, many of these billions of aid did not exist at all. If we had abandoned many of the EU's monetary tanks, much of the problem would have solved itself. Secondly, if you had really wanted to take action on the rule of law, you would have started somewhere else entirely. Then you started with Turkey. Although Turkey is not a member, it receives billions of euros from the EU. Let's start there. But there is no will to do so - funny enough. There are plenty of facts around Europe that can be rightly criticised, but I think hypocrisy is drifting down the walls of this Chamber when, at the same time, the unscrupulous dictator in Turkey is being laughed at.

name: Alexandra Geese (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Minister of State Roth, I would like to thank the Commissioner for His work and For the Way in which she has Thank you for the fine words you have found, but I believe you know for yourself that the proposal that you have to defend here on behalf of the Council is totally inadequate to achieve this objective. And to my colleagues on the right of the House, I would also like to say to you that this is not about imposing values on the countries of Europe that are alien to them. I find it exciting how you are dropping the mask here and saying that the rule of law, freedom of the press and democracy are foreign values. These are all values to which our countries have made explicit support when they joined, because that is exactly what they wanted. It is precisely in countries where people have suffered under dictatorships that these values, these fundamental rights, these clearly securitised fundamental rights, and the separation of powers are so important. Nor is it a question of punishing countries, but the European Union must not use subsidies to promote authoritarian regimes. This is exactly what is going to happen: that those in power are enriching themselves, that freedoms will be restricted even more. At a time when we are once again distributing 750 billion in addition to the multiannual financial framework, we must state quite clearly here: this is not the way to go! We need the rule of law mechanism now. This is also something that the majority of European citizens are calling for very loudly, and we must defend that here. We stand here for them.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate, I would like to emphasise that the German Presidency's proposal to link the disbursements from the future EU budget to the so-called rule of law is grossly inconsistent with the findings made at the European Council in Brussels on 21 July. Although the Heads of Government agreed at the time to such a link, the mechanism was aimed at combating risks in the spending of European funds, such as corruption, mismanagement and embezzlement. The German Presidency, in order to live up to the most radical expectations expressed here in this House, mainly by the left, proposes a mechanism to give the European Commission, in principle, a free hand in arbitrarily punishing the Member States.  Mr Roth, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner Reynders, i would like to thank you for your comments. You do not want to protect the financial interests of the European Union, as you have said here. You want to prepare an ideological baton that you will put on the governments of the Member States that you do not like. Poland and other Member States have never... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Sira Rego (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that in a debate like this it is inevitable to wonder when it began to seem normal for us to discuss the need for the rule of law to be complied with in Europe or not. At what point have we accepted that two far-right governments will impose their agenda and normalize non-compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The truth is that my feeling is that, deep down, what we are doing here is agreeing how indifferent we will be to the infringement of rights in certain States. For example, how indifferent we will be to Hungary gassing migrants at its border, or how much against that Poland that declares LGTBI people-free zones. What's more, how indifferent we are going to be to those who hate us, to women. In short, what is being debated here is about a false disjunction in order to access public money. But there are no intermediate positions. Human rights are fulfilled or not fulfilled. And it is up to us to demand that they be fulfilled. That is why the vague formula they put in the Council, in substance, makes them complicit.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: Mr President, is it a good idea to withhold subsidies in the case of undesirable situations in The Member States? The short answer is no. Just as practical. EU subsidies are – if it is right – very much needed to achieve EU objectives. If the flow of money stops, the project will stop and objectives will not be met. Moreover, connecting political purposes to money flows is corrupting and disruptive. Perverse incentives never lead to a desired outcome.  The Netherlands should know all this better than anyone. After 1975, the country messed up the situation in its former colony of Suriname for years with this carrot-and-stick approach. It doesn't work. I share the genuine concern about the legitimate use of EU funds. But this can also be handled differently and better, for example by simply making EU subsidies and their use available in real time on the European Commission's website, so that they can be consulted by everyone. This allows every citizen to monitor the course of events.  The development of democratic legal states takes time. Take that time and give that time.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, respecting the rule of law and the values of the European Union must be an obligation, it cannot be an option. Moreover, I am very impressed that the Member States which, in order to enter the European Union, have met the criteria for their support, have committed themselves to respecting the values, after being in the European Union they no longer respect those same values and go back. It's a setback that's not acceptable. Nor is it acceptable for European taxpayers, European citizens, to pay and contribute to those who are not respecting the rule of law. And in that sense, I think we should all be in the same boat, we should all work for that respect. And there is something, and I will end, which I find doubly unacceptable: apart from this lack of solidarity, it is unacceptable that Member States that do not respect the rule of law at the same time want to blackmail, such as the Recovery Fund, which is essential for the European Union.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Minister Roth, Commissioner Hahn, it is never to oin so much to remember that the Copenhagen criteria establish, and I quote, "the stability of the institutions that guarantee democracy, the rule of law, human rights and respect for minorities and their protection", for example. Every country has known since 1993 that, in order to be a candidate for a Member State of the European Union, it must respect this principle. And in order for negotiations to begin, the country must meet the first criterion. This one, what I quoted. However, no country can fail to respect it from the moment it becomes a full member. It's an obligation of all 27. This is also the direction of the European Commission's report. This is the European Union we want. The funding which the European Union has, or is able to make available to the Member States, i.e. the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Recovery Fund, is financed, directly or indirectly, by the money of European citizens. And principles such as transparency and the proper use of public money prevail, but the commitment of European political priorities, the commitment to European values, also prevails. That is why we need a robust mechanism that protects the final beneficiaries, that protects European values, that does not call into question the European Union's ability to respond to this crisis in a European response. It is an expectation that we have already created it with European citizens, in particular with the creation of the Recovery Fund.  And we trust you, Minister Roth, to reach an agreement on a rule of law mechanism in the Council.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Minister Roth for his very personal commitment, but we have to recognise that Council has basically passed on the hot potato to the European Parliament because a majority of governments secretly hopes that Parliament will do their dirty work for them, because they are being held hostage by the autocrats in their midst. And that is why reverse QMV has to be a red line for this House. And let’s not fall into the trap that we have to accept a trade-off, either the rule of law or some of our other demands like our resources, for example, because we don’t, because this is not about money, this is about what kind of European Union will be funded with taxpayers’ money in the next seven years. Will it be the illiberal democracy of Orbán and his Orbanettes or will it be a European community of values and a community of law? Colleagues, we have one opportunity. One. We cannot fail.  (Applause)

name: Vincenzo Sofo (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President von der Leyen has revealed to this House her desire to use the COVID crisis to impose multiculturalist, immigrant and LGBT ideology in Europe, announcing that respect for the so-called rule of law will become a condition of access to the Recovery Fund. Well, a condition already used by the Commission in its monitoring report to order Italy to stop, for example, the campaigns to denounce NGOs importing migrants into Europe. It is therefore clear that the rule of law is nothing more than a sneaky weapon to blackmail the peoples of Europe brought to their knees by the health crisis and submit them to the dictatorship of the 'politically correct', in exchange for the hope of obtaining money that, in reality, does not belong to you but to the sacrifices of these same peoples. I say this to you, therefore, clearly: get out of your head to use the pandemic to impose, by means of loan bottlenecks, indiscriminate reception, LGBT follies, ad hoc recruitment for immigrants, in short, to impose by blackmail the work of destroying European civilisation that you cannot impose with democracy.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we need a strong and functional rule of law conditionality for the EU budget – an overwhelming majority in this Parliament agrees on this. The arguments why have been exchanged extensively. What I find particularly interesting are the arguments against. The Polish and the Hungarian governments have repeatedly claimed – and we have also heard this again today in this Chamber – that this is merely some kind of left-wing evil conspiracy against conservative values in the European Union. What absolute utter nonsense. Because if we look at this proposal, at this conditionality, it is actually exactly that at its core. It’s conservative. It is law-and-order politics at its best. You play by the rules that all Member States – again, all Member States – have jointly agreed on, or you live with the consequences. And the consequences might mean that you cannot distribute EU money to your liking anymore. I want to show you: this is where the big consensus in the European Parliament starts, on this left side, and then it goes all the way up until here – the EPP. This is not a left-wing conspiracy. Let’s go back to reality and talk about real arguments. We need this conditionality and we need it now.

name: Cristian Terheş (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to colleagues in this House about making European funds conditional for respect for the rule of law. Anyone in the European Union who has listened to this debate would have expected to hear experts today or to hear colleagues in this House talk about arguments, principles, values and methods of measuring what the rule of law means in Europe.  What we have heard today, however, is about the implementation of this mechanism to make European funds conditional under the pretext of respecting the rule of law, in fact, to press various states or governments or to make money conditional on certain governments, if they do not accept a certain direction coming from Brussels. The idea of the rule of law is to let arguments beat the majority.  There has been talk in this room today about the fact that there is a certain majority. However, no arguments were spoken of. A colleague in Renew was talking about the fact that this report must, and I quote, "be a professional and objective report". We have the case of the report on Romania which is neither objective nor professional.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The rule of law is non-negotiable. It is a pity that Europe's values are now being misused as a pledge in the financial negotiations. That is why Parliament can only go one direction: without a strong link between the money in law and order, there can be no Corona fund, no MFF, no business as usual. Then we will continue with the previous budget, let a year pass – I am relatively calm about that. European Rule of Law is a clear condition. But there are others. The Recovery Fund must be clearly invested in European added value: in the energy transition, in modern health systems, in research. If this fund is misused to finance ordinary government spending, it is not a reconstruction. Then we have four years of straw fire and 40 years of debt for nothing. Here, too, we must show a clear edge. Without binding European added value, the Reconstruction Fund makes as little sense as it does without a link to a functioning legal system.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Before we proceed with the debate, I will open today's voting round. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found in the agenda adopted today. The voting round is open from 7.15 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. The voting procedure is the same as in the last part-sessions. All votes are roll-call votes and Members may check their vote and the results of the votes on the basis of the document published on the plenary session's website. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, explanations of vote may not contain more than 400 words. I declare the first round of voting open. You can now vote until 8.30 p.m. The results of the vote will be announced tomorrow at 9 a.m.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the Council and Commission statements on the rule of law conditionality in the framework of MFF 2021-2027 and "Next Generation EU" (2020/2797(RSP)).

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The start of the plenary week and three directly three debates on democracy and the rule of law.  Next Generation? Orban, Kaczysski and Co. continue to pursue their anti-democratic path– partly with the help of EU funds. Strengthening the democratic rule of law is a priority of the German Presidency – but really for everyone? In any case, the compromise on conditionality that has now been presented is disappointing.  No reversequalified majority, which would have made the cancellation of EU funds almost automatically possible, and the procedures can be lengthened endlessly. The risk of endangering the rule of law: deleted. What is needed now is a sufficiently direct threat to the budget.  Next Generation? My 'Next Generation EU' would not be that. That is why the Council must finally take a clear position on our democracy.

name: Sandro Gozi (Renew).
text: Madam President, we have a unique opportunity, so I am speaking to the Council, dear Michael Roth. This time, really put the rule of law at the heart of the budget. This time, win the rule of law against the reason of state. No one believes in the blackmail of Viktor Orban. He's bluffing when he says he's going to block the stimulus package. Let's not be afraid to unmask him. Let's be more ambitious in terms of implementation. Dear Michael Roth, the rule of law is much more than just protecting financial interests. This is our freedoms! And conditionality is the only way to regain mutual trust between us on the recovery plan.  But let's not punish citizens twice. We have proposed intelligent conditionality. The Commission must directly manage the funds in the event of a violation of the rule of law because it is the governments that must be punished, not the citizens. And let us remember what Martin Luther King said: a delayed right is a denied right. This time, let's ensure a real protection of our values!

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen (ID).
text: – Mr President, is the EU the right body to discuss the rule of law? At the same time, people who do not respect anyone's rights, neither minorities nor anyone else with Western principles, are allowed into Europe. Right now, in the context of the recovery package, it is a bullish violation of its own rules, but requires absolute obedience on the part of the Member States.  The whole debate on the rule of law is yet another example of the EU's shackled grip. There is a desire to deprive the Member States of the last remnants of their own decision-making power. Each country is different. Each country has a long cultural heritage of its own values. It is natural that the eu's often schem models and commands, dictated by the big Member States, are not suitable for all countries.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, we have only talked for a decade in this European Union about structural adjustments and budget cuts at the expense of essential public services and populations. The Commission has just published its first annual report on the rule of law and says it wants to create a culture of the rule of law between us. It is a good initiative and it is a good report. But if the issues of freedoms and rights remain only the subject of hushed discussions in our national parliaments and the subject, once a year, of an essay in the European Parliament, where we will say with a distressed air that 'the rule of law is not improving in the European Union', then we will have failed. Why does the Commission not hesitate to trigger infringement proceedings when it comes to financial or competitive problems? How can we explain why its experts are still able to find legal grounds? Why do the Member States not hesitate to isolate one of their own when it deviates from monetary rules, which can have terrible consequences on the people, but we fail to create a financial mechanism of sanctions worthy of its name when autocrats divert our common money by reducing freedoms and democracy?

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have no words when I see the German Presidency failing to keep its word at the July summit. I have no words when I see the Manipulation of the European Commission on how to circumvent Article 7, even though the Council's legal services say explicitly that this mechanism is a duplication of Article 7. I have no words when I hear the German Vice-President of the European Parliament, Barley, talking about starking a Member State, and then brazenly speaking in Parliament and talking about values.  I have no words, Madam President, when I hear the German Presidency talk about justice and the rule of law. Maybe it is high time that you declared the payment of the reparations due to Poland? Extermination of 6 million Polish citizens, looting of Polish assets, equating with the land of Warsaw, extermination of Polish elites. And I have no words when, for the sake of democracy, you do not respect democratic governance in Warsaw.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I'm Hungarian, I love my country, and I love freedom. I fought for my country and for freedom against the Communist dictatorship. I am a citizen of a country that has been declared ill for greater glory by the rule of law, Commissioner Jourová. I belong to the community, the Community of Hungarians, about which the liberal Jourová, led by a deep commitment to the rule of law, said that the majority of Hungarians could not form their own opinions. And in the name of the rule of law, my country has recently been threatened by the German Socialist Vice-President of the European Parliament, Congresswoman Barley, that she must be financially starved. Insults, threats, political blackmail, power arrogance. This is completely unacceptable. Dear Minister Roth, These voices do remind us of the striding Communist Party secretaries of the 1970s and 1980s, who represented that either we accept their violent party ideals or we are doomed. We could handle them and earn our freedom. We're going to deal with these attacks. (The President shrugs off the word)

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer acceptable for governments, such as the Polish and Hungarian governments, to blackmail – yes, I use that word, blackmail! - the other European executives calling for the rule of law to be ignored in exchange for a faster departure of Next Generation EU. The recovery plan cannot and must not depend on the whims and bluffs, as has already been said, of the nationalists: we must be united, isolating these dangerous positions. We must protect our European model based on a strong welfare state and on the rights of freedom because, while nationalist and extreme right-wing political leaders talk of an abstract defence of values, it is in fact they who do not defend at all the values of freedom, equality, democracy and self-determination of which the Union is the expression. That is why we need an ambitious agreement on conditionality linked to respect for the rule of law, because starting again after the pandemic also means changing, it means getting the resources for recovery to our territories soon and it also means fighting for respect for democratic rights and freedoms throughout the Territory of the Union, without exclusion.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, this in my hand is the European Commission’s annual report on Hungary’s rule of law situation. It says that there is a systemic lack of determined action to investigate and prosecute corruption cases involving high—level officials or their immediate circles. And this is the 2019 report of OLAF, the European Union’s anti—fraud body, which shows that financial irregularities in Hungary are ten times above the EU’s average. So what we have is that the European Union’s official position is that we have a Member State where corruption is off the charts, and there are basically no guarantees against the government pocketing EU taxpayers’ money. So the question is obvious: when are we going to do something about it? When the rule of law is in danger, these projects should be directly managed by the Commission so that they reach the final beneficiaries, the small businesses, the civil society, those who need it the most. Because let’s face it, words are not enough anymore. Let’s act. There is a pandemic raging around us. We need to help those who are in need. (Applause)

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, trying to solve the health crisis and the economic crisis without ensuring that the rule of law is respected is like repairing the roof of a building with sagging floors. We can no longer stay silent to the numerous rule of law violations in the EU, and we need an effective instrument and the political courage to bring an end to impunity. The EU budget will grow unprecedentedly high. We must use this momentum not only because of the financial interests of the EU, but also because it creates the opportunity to use the interest of autocrats like Orbán in EU money. But the Council position gives the impression that Member States don’t want an effective instrument. What message do they send to the citizens under threat? We are one Union but you need to fight for your own rights? That is really justifying actually the distrust that many citizens already have in the EU. I call on you: let us make sure that this will not happen. We need conditionality on all aspects of the rule-of-law, not only corruption and fraud. We need to stay united as a Parliament and don’t let the Member States leave us with empty hands. After all, we’re not here to defeat our governments, but... (the President cut the speaker off)

name: Jörgen Warborn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Citizens' trust is the basis for European cooperation. Taxpayers should feel confident that their money is being spent properly. Unfortunately, we see many examples across Europe where the rule of law is being disregarded. For us in the Moderate Party, a strong rule of law mechanism is crucial. We need to be much sharper in following up on the use of EU funds. However, the new proposal from the Presidency is too pale and too watered down. We have to go much harder. Not a dime should go to governments that challenge democracy or foment corruption. That must be a clear principle in this budget and in all future budgets. It is basically a question of the credibility of the whole of European cooperation, that we have control over how the money is spent. Corrupt and undemocratic forces should not be fattened by the Swedish taxpayers.

name: Dragoş Tudorache (Renew).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate, in fact, should not have taken place, for the simple reason that the rule of law is an elementary value for a democracy and it should no longer be the subject of discussion, all the more so it should not be the subject of negotiation between the Council and Parliament or the subject of conditionality. But here we are, unfortunately, in a situation where Member States are forcing the internal balances of the rule of law, and this reality can no longer be ignored or hidden under the mat! We need effective correction and conditioning mechanisms, we need a mechanism to make governments have access to European money, while respecting direct beneficiaries and with an effective reverse majority decision-making mechanism. The citizens who voted for us a year ago expect us to be consistent with the fundamental values that define them as nations and all of us as Europeans.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I can only agree with what the previous speaker said, that such a discussion is not really necessary here. I was all the more perplexed to listen to what Mr Hakkarainen said – but he went straight after what he said – who said that it is not the job of European institutions to talk about constitutional matters. Where else should we and must we talk about this issue? Especially when there are obvious problems and when that is addressed. In this respect, I am grateful for this debate and for the strong commitment of this House, which does not surprise me either, and also for the fact that there is a strong commitment on the part of the Council, Minister of State Roth. The fact that the Commission has, so to speak, divided its speech here today between the Commissioner for Legal Affairs and the Commissioner for Budgets is also an expression of the fact that this is a package, that this must be seen together, that the issue of the rule of law, conditionality, is an integral part of the European budget. I hope that, in the next few weeks, we will not reach agreement here , and I am saying this now as Commissioner for Budgets – in the face of all the difficulties, an agreement that respects the principles of the rule of law, which are necessary for a serious implementation of the budget, but which, at the same time, understands that we are in a difficult situation. Across Europe, the number of infections is soaring, and the economy is still suffering. We will have a double-digit economic downturn in virtually all countries. We are called upon to provide our citizens quickly and as easily as possible with the mechanisms that we have proposed – MFF, 'Next Generation EU', SURE – but to do so in the face of the necessary principles of the rule of law.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are not having a debate on governments today, we are having a debate on a new instrument today. I would like to reassure you that we agree in principle that, after many years, when there was no agreement on this instrument, this instrument was not yet on the table as a concrete proposal – we have only been talking about it since 2018 – and we have a unique opportunity to use a new instrument to help us regain new certainty about it. , who we really are in the European Union and where we want to go together. I regard it as a sign of the highest level of commitment that there is a lot of controversy here in the European Parliament and that there is also a clear criticism. However, I would ask you to do one thing: let us talk about the content! We are not the accomplices of criminals, nor do I fall to my knees before any dictator. I think that, despite the understandable emotionality, we should try to keep looking at where we can move towards each other and how we can move towards each other. I would also ask for respect for the different roles of these bodies. A Member of Parliament has just sat down and said that if it goes after him, it will have time with 'Next Generation EU'. I have always understood this differently, honourable Members. I have always understood this in such a way that we have all made a common promise that the necessary means to combat the pandemic will be as quickly as possible where they are most needed. Yes, and there is a difficulty that we in the Council have to overcome. You can count on us to address this difficulty. But with respect, on an equal footing. We need unanimity for the regulation on the multiannual financial framework and we need unanimity for the own resources decision. We even need ratification in all 27 Member States for the own resources decision. The President of this Parliament has repeatedly asked critically, in the direction of my own country, whether we can do so in the few weeks that remain. With SURE, as you will remember, the national ratification process has also taken a long time. In this respect, I would like to reassure you that, for all the difficulties of getting it off the way without the agreement of all the national delegations, this mandate is an honest offer for honest negotiations with the European Parliament. We would like to see a speedy conclusion on the overall package.  Of course, it is about the principles of the rule of law. If the Commission has a central role to play in all the proposals and considerations before me, then I also take very seriously what the Commission has said so far about the core elements of the rule of law. Then I take note that it is not just a question of budgetary issues. It is about the independence of the judiciary, it is about checks and balances, it is about an effective fight against corruption, and it is about media pluralism and freedom of the media. And we take that seriously. There is also a specific reference to Article 2 in this draft, because we are aware of the difficulties and because we are aware of the fact that the European Court of Justice has repeatedly applied serious gravamina in some Member States. But it is an instrument for all of us.  That is why I would ask you all: let us not deny our intentions! Let us now move quickly into the final stage of the outstanding negotiations and make it clear that the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament are pulling together on issues of the rule of law, and that this is still in the same direction if possible! The German Presidency is very happy to do so with your support.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Before we get to the next item on the agenda, I would like to inform my fellow Members of this House that interpreters from Malta and Ireland are only available to a limited extent because of travel restrictions and that, therefore, from 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m., only passive interpretation from Maltese and Gaelic to other languages is guaranteed, that is to say, everyone can speak in their own language, but only the other languages will be interpreted during this period. We hope that travel restrictions will soon be reduced and lifted. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D)
text: in writing. – Article 2 of the Treaty sets out the fundamental values of the EU and the role of the European Commission is to ensure compliance with the Treaties. A strong Commission is essential for the proper functioning of the Union, which cannot be alibied by council blockades. At the moment the debate on the rule of law is, if possible, more important because of its relationship with the issues that will surely be the most important for the coming years: financial framework, own resources and recovery plan. We do not have to choose between democratic quality and economic recovery, but both are possible and that is why we ask for responsibility, not to feed divisions and not to take democracy for granted in the face of the rise of populs. We consider it important that this message reach citizenship and that is why we insist that the final recipients of the funds are not harmed. Our group has long asked for a mechanism of respect for the rule of law, linked to the budget and finally we have a proposal with which to start negotiating. It is now important to reach an agreement as soon as possible so that programs can boot without delay.

name: Marc Angel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Given the current circumstances, where some of our Member States do not respect fundamental rights and where right-wing, fascist and anti-gender movements are at the forefront, the German Presidency’s approved proposal on a mechanism on the rule of law is just not enough. This proposal, which limits itself to purely protection of the EU budget, will not help us achieve our goals on safeguarding European values and fundamental rights. There is a fundamental misunderstanding, because the ‘financial interest of the Union’ is not a goal in itself! We should not adopt a regulation to ‘protect the Union budget in the case of breaches of the principles of rule of law in the Member States’, but the other way around. This proposal will not bring us any further than the Article 7 procedures. There, the EP should refuse any deal on the MFF as long as there is no clear commitment on a serious mechanism on the rule of law with a reverse qualified majority and without the need for a direct impact on the EU budget in case of a violation of the rule of law.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today we are faced with a bizarre situation where a large part of the EP is trying at all costs to instrumentalise the concept of the rule of law. Unfortunately, left-wing factions in this House are at the fore front of anything to achieve their goal of affirming left-wing pseudo-values while destroying all manifestations of Christian or conservative thinking and action. Poland is placed under the pillory of international institutions on the basis of obvious fake news. This debate discusses further instruments to put pressure on EU Member States, instruments completely detached from the EU Treaties. German politician, EP Vice-President Katarina Barley, talks about the "starking" of Polish and Hungary. He talks about a country where Germans were brutally murdered for death by starvation. This speaks in the context of today's debate, in the discussion on the conditionality mechanism in the EU budget and the suspension of funds for violations of the rule of law.  How far can you go in ideological blindness? Can anyone identify EU rules or treaty provisions that define so-called rule of law violations? There is no question of agreeing to a regulation which is based on vaguely defined terms and conditions. It would pave the way for us to act at any time against the financial interests of the selected EU Member States, and we must not accept this.

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is a community that is based on equality of all states. Poland does not agree to the role of the second category, where other countries interfere in its internal policy, which is outside the EU's competence. The current EU pressure is a political action and has nothing to do with the rule of law. We have our rights, Poland has the right to reform, it was poles in democratic elections who decided on the need for change. In reform, we follow the rules in force in the EU and in the Member States.  The mechanism for linking the budget to breaches in the area of the rule of law (breach of the values referred to in Article 2 OF the TOU) should be permanently removed from the draft regulation. It duplicates the mechanism under Article 7 TEU, marginalising the role of the Council of the EU and the European Council in the process of assessing a Member State's breach of the rule of law, and deprives the Article 7 procedure of multi-step nature, thereby violating the rights of the Member State to which the allegations are addressed. The introduction of a link between the budget and the rule of law, separate from Article 7 OF the TOU, is without treaty grounds. For this reason, Poland does not agree with the content of the new draft regulation presented by the German Presidency on 27 September 2020. Poland was also against giving the Presidency a mandate to open negotiations with the EP on the basis of this version of the draft.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am not particularly pleased that we are in a situation where we are forced to have a discussion on linking the disbursements of EU funds to the issue of member states' compliance with the rule of law. Compliance with that principle must be obvious and natural for the Member States.  The European Union is not only a common market, it is also a common principle and values. Moreover, even if we were still at the earliest stage of integration, at the stage of the common market, it would be indispensable to respect the rule of law, which builds legal certainty and confidence. Let us also emphasise that this principle is not a question of theory, it is ultimately the taking away of the right to freedom, security and access to an independent court for individuals. But since the anti-democratic actions of some governments have already forced us to discuss this and to work on the relevant legislation in this area, I would like to stress strongly: there is no place in the European Union for violations of the rule of law, and we must do everything to ensure that this does not happen. And do so so that the consequences are not borne by EU citizens, but by anti-democratic governments.  I therefore believe that disbursements should be resumed immediately when violations of the rule of law subside. I am also in favour of a mechanism that will ensure the disbursement of funds to final beneficiaries, for example NGOs or local governments, without central governments that are in power that are in power.
