name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We have welcomed the progress of legislative work in the Council on a draft regulation providing for the establishment of a budgetary conditionality mechanism. However, the member states' compromise differs significantly from the Position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading.  First of all, the Council is narrowing the application of the Regulation, combining respect for the rule of law with the protection of the EU's financial interests. This move may seem in some way justified in the context of opinions suggesting an unacceptable duplication in the EP-Council Regulation of the Treaty Mechanism for the Protection of the Rule of Law. It should be borne in mind, however, that Article 7 of the TOU has proved to be completely ineffective. This is a fundamental problem that threatens to destroy the Union in the long term. I therefore believe that, as the European Parliament, we should strive to protect all the values of Article 2 of the EU HERE more effectively. Our vote cannot be ignored by the Member States in the Council, although in today's realities, the establishment of a general budgetary conditionality mechanism is a real challenge , both politically and legally.  We cannot limit ourself to recognising the compromise of the German Presidency and it is necessary to seek further solutions. I hope that Parliament will continue to present a principled position on this regulation and seek to modify it in line with the position taken at first reading. It is critical to reintroduc the reverse qualified majority voting method in the Council when implementing sanctions and to effectively protect the beneficiaries of the final Union funds.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Only a common solution at EU level can be provided for the economic, social and health crisis caused by the coronavirus. The European Union has put on the table an unprecedented amount of bailouts in order to adequately address the negative economic, social and health effects of the coronavirus. Payments under the MTA 2021-2027 and EU funds from the Next Generation EU would be subject to the Commission's rule of law conditions, which would be blocked in the Council by the Hungarian Government, among others. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Let us not give in to the blackmail of populist, far-right governments that crush EU values. We must asent the rule of law, because our task is to protect the interests of EU taxpayers. The Orban government uses EU funds to enrich close relatives and friends, not to help the Hungarian people. In order to prevent this, the rule of law should be introduced, but in the case of Member States that do not respect EU values, EU financial assistance can be provided to taxpayers through municipalities, small and medium-sized enterprises. We are fighting for the European Union to serve the interests of EU citizens!

name: Mihai Tudose (S&D)
text: in writing. – Negotiations are under way between the Council and Parliament on making European funds conditional on respect for the rule of law. Unfortunately, the positions of the two co-legislators - defined in the Council of 17-21 July, respectively by the European Parliament resolution which I voted on 23 July - seem difficult to harmonise.  I therefore call for the correct ordering of priorities, in line with the reality faced by the citizens of the Union. Let us not forget how difficult the agreement to create the recovery instrument was achieved at the second longest summit in the history of the EU. But let us also not neglect the need to protect the EU budget, when there is a systemic threat to the values underlying the European project.  There is a risk of the adoption of the EU budget for the next seven years in the European Parliament if we do not see the Council opening up to the creation of the mechanism to make European funds conditional on respect for the principles of the rule of law. In order to be functional, this mechanism must be able to be activated by a qualified majority in the Council. Countries that joined the EU 16 years ago face worrying democratic involutions. We need a European framework that responds to new challenges, without losing sight of the health and economic emergency for a moment!

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – Worthy President, last week the European Commission published its first report on the rule of law. For some Member States, the report is grim reading. The rule of law and the realisation of fundamental freedoms and democracy are under serious threat in these Member States. This is extremely worrying, because these European values form the foundations of the European Union on which european cooperation as a whole is built.  In a joint text this week, the group leaders of the European Parliament reaffirmed parliament's position that Parliament will not give its assent to the eu's new long-term budget if the use of funds is not tied to the rule of law. Parliament is not prepared to adopt a rule of law mechanism that would not effectively address the problems of the rule of law in the Member States where, according to the Commission's assessment, they exist. The current proposal from the Council of Ministers is a long way from this. The negotiations on the EU's long-term budget and the linking of the use of funds to the rule of law are, for many years, the only real possibility of tackling negative rule of law developments. The EU cannot afford to lose that.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Bulgaria (2020/2793(RSP)). I would point out to Members that no spontaneous speeches or blue cards are accepted in all the debates of this part-session.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioners for their work and for the way in Once again, we have the opportunity to discuss the issues of the rule of law. I would like to make it brief at the outset, but I would like to use concrete examples to point out how seriously the Council, as well as the German Presidency of the Council of the EU, is serious about learning from the experience gained so far and making it better. Once again, the rule of law is not just a guiding principle to which the institutions and bodies of the European Union must submit. No, the rule of law applies to all Member States without exception. I am therefore very, very grateful – and I would like to emphasise this once again – that we in the Council now also have the opportunity to take a major step forward in highlighting precisely this common ground in terms of values, the principle of the rule of law, democratic culture and not just what is unfortunately dividing us at the moment. The new Rule of Law Check, based on the Commission's report, plays a very central role in this. We will now have a first debate in October on the general situation of the rule of law in the European Union, and we, as the Presidency of the Council, then proposed that each country be reviewed in detail. In order to have a sound, objective, non-discriminatory debate, but also evidence-based, we will start with five Member States. This will then be Belgium, Denmark, Estonia, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic in November according to the alphabetical order. We will therefore also be discussing the situation in the country that is also the subject of your debate today. I am very happy to take your suggestions and your comments with me, also as a sign that you agree with us that the rule of law is an obligation for all and not just for a few.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for putting the item on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Bulgaria on the plenary agenda today. The Commission is aware of the protests in Bulgaria and we have been following the situation closely. Let me start by being very clear on an important point: the Commission fully supports the right to demonstrate peacefully. Peaceful demonstrations constitute the exercise of a fundamental right which exists in all democratic countries and must be fully respected. The demonstrations show that citizens attach great importance to an independent and efficient judiciary and also to good governance. The Commission is also aware of the announcement made by Prime Minister Borisov on a possible revision of the Bulgarian Constitution. It is not for the Commission to comment at this stage on the details of the proposed reforms. However, we stand ready to support Bulgaria in its reform process.  As I already said in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) in September, like in any Member State, constitutional reform should be subject to a large and inclusive debate, take the time to be able to reflect a large consensus and achieve the necessary checks and balances. A best practice is to seek the specific advice of organisations like the Venice Commission.  Now let me turn to the cooperation and verification mechanism (CVM). As regards the CVM, as you know, it had been set up at accession to help Bulgaria in making reforms and to allow for monitoring this reform process based on a given set of benchmarks to achieve. The Commission considers that the CVM has proven to be instrumental in the reform process, which has put in place legal and institutional measures to address the mechanism’s objectives.  As underlined in the October 2019 CVM report, Bulgaria made sufficient progress to meet the commitments made at the time of accession. The situation now, looked at from the perspective of its institutional and legislative framework, is no longer the situation of 2007. At the same time, in the October 2019 CVM report, the Commission was also clear that Bulgaria needs to ensure continued implementation of the necessary reforms, notably relating to judicial independence and the fight against corruption. Wrapping up any leftover from the accession process has always been the objective of the Commission. It emphasises the need for stability, and no backtracking on past structural achievements and continuity, which means pursuit of the implementation of reforms and the fight against corruption and organised crime.  Before taking a final decision on lifting the CVM in Bulgaria, the Commission will also take duly into account the observations of the European Parliament and also of the Council. It would be premature to give a date at this stage. (Interruption owing to problems with microphone) Mr President, thank you very much for your help. You will see from what I am going to say that it was indeed important, because the only missing sentence was that the Commission will continue following the developments in Bulgaria. It remains essential that these do not reverse the course of progress underlying the baseline assessment of January 2017.  (Applause)

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will continue with the last words of Vice-President Jourová, because our work does not stop here, of course, and the Commission will continue to work with Bulgaria under the new rule of law mechanism, as it does with all the Member States. The scope of the rule of law mechanism is broader than the cooperation and verification mechanism (CVM) and it covers not only judicial reform and the fight against corruption, but also – as we have discussed just before – freedom and privileges, as well as institutional checks and balances. The rule of law report was just adopted last week and, as I explained in my presentation to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) last week or around then, the report on the country chapters developed for each Member State cover the rule of law situation in all of them, including Bulgaria.  More particularly, as regards Bulgaria, let me underline some of the most significant developments taken into account in the report. As regards judicial independence, Bulgaria still needs to finalise, taking account of the opinion of the Venice Commission, legal procedures concerning the effective accountability and criminal liability of the Prosecutor—General. In addition, the composition and functioning of the Supreme Judicial Council has been subject of further debate. On a more positive tone, controversial provisions relating to the automatic suspensions of magistrates in case of a criminal investigation and to the obligation for magistrates to declare their membership in professional organisations have been repealed. However, and it also confirms past CVM findings, despite a comprehensive reform of its legal and institutional anti-corruption framework and improved cooperation between the authorities, there is still the need to establish a solid track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases. It is important that the authorities are provided with sufficient resources in order to be able to fight corruption effectively. The necessary strictures are essentially in place, but Bulgaria has to make them deliver reserves more efficiently. Lack of reserves in the fight against corruption is one of the key aspects raised throughout the ongoing process. Perception surveys show a very low level of public trust in the anti-corruption institutions. It is important to show that there is political will to fight corruption in a credible manner.  As to media privilege, the legal framework is in place, but safeguards are often not effectively implemented in practice. In addition, lack of transparency of media ownership is considered a source of concern. Finally, the issues concerning checks and balances include concerns about the limited use of public consultations and impact assessments in the legislative process. Furthermore, the already narrow civic space in Bulgaria could be further affected in view of a new draft law on foreign funding for NGOs.  To conclude, let me reiterate once more that the Commission is determined to continue to use all the instruments at its disposal to address the concerns identified in the country. I am convinced that it is important to look at all the Member States in a fully objective and comparable manner. This is what we are now doing with the new rule of law report, and the Commission appreciates the continued support of the European Parliament in this respect. Of course, we have been working for some years about the CVM, but we continue, also, to work with the annual report of the rule of law with a broader scope on all the Member States, including Bulgaria.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work on the work he has Yes, Bulgaria is a country that is on its way, and there is still a long way to go to implement the standards that we have all set ourselves in Europe. Yes, it must also be said that not everything is perfect in Bulgaria. That is why I think it is good that young people are taking to the streets, that they are demonstrating that they represent their positions, that they are putting their ideas on the way. Young people in particular do not understand that it takes a long time; they want to make rapid progress. That is good to see. The facts that characterise Bulgaria were described last week by the Commission's report, which is fair, balanced, fact-based, and should be the basis for further work. As I said, the Bulgarians, however, can also be proud of what has been achieved, despite all the tasks that are ahead of them. That, too, must be noted first. Today, however, we are not talking about the general situation, but about Rule of Law. Rule of Law, for example, indicates that democracy works. We have a government of the European People's Party in Bulgaria, and we have a socialist President who has come into office democratically. Balance of Power – two different parties are responsible there. We have the principle that freedom of the media, of opinion, must be guaranteed: since the summer, every weekend and permanent demonstrations have been held there, young people take to the streets, can show what positions they have. After all, no one can say that we do not have freedom of the media and the press and freedom of expression there. Boyko Borisov has always explicitly protected this will of young people. He always protected the demonstrators, and he said, "Go out on the streets and show your opinion!" We must also state in Rule of Law that we have respect for an election result. The current government has a majority in Parliament, is elected by the citizens. That is why there is absolutely no reason to resign now and to temporarily bring an unelected government into office, especially in the coronating times. It should also be noted that, of course, some progress has been made in the area of the rule of law. Especially in the area of smuggling activities, the numbers have been significantly reduced. I would also like to say explicitly that Boyko Borisov is leading a pro-European government. He helped to launch the introduction of the euro and, as far as the issue is today, he has always supported the Rule of Law mechanism in the Council, which we in the European Parliament are calling for here. Boyko Borisov wants this Rule of Law mechanism. So, it remains to be said that not everything is perfect, that many tasks are still ahead of the Bulgarian Government, but that Bulgaria is essentially on the right track. To the demonstrators only a request and a clarification: a change in the government is not achieved by demonstrations, but by means of elections, and these will take place next year in March, and everyone should participate. Then the citizens of Bulgaria will decide how to proceed.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, again a debate on the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. Is it fun, is it nice to bring to this European Parliament a resolution expressing concern about the rule of law in a Member State? It certainly isn't. But it may be painfully necessary: in this case, Bulgaria, a recently accession state, which was incorporated with a mechanism for cooperation and verification of its progress in judicial reform and anti-corruption, but what we have seen in recent times is not progress, but worrying setbacks.  'Rule of law' means respect for the judgments of the courts, and forty-five convictions of the European Court of Human Rights are accumulated pending compliance in accordance with the report of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe.  "Rule of Law" means separation of powers, and we see continuing allegations and accusations of judicial corruption and political intervention by the Public Prosecutor's Office in pursuit of political adversaries.  "Rule of law" also means respect for freedoms, and we see concentration of media by the Government and also clientelism in those media that remain in private hands.  And "rule of law" also means respecting public freedoms, the right to demonstration, and we have attended exercises of police brutality, as well as persecution of minorities.  We therefore express (inaudible words) Bulgaria and say that this does not in any case mean a charge against Bulgaria. It means that this European Parliament, as with Hungary, ten million Hungarian citizens, and Poland, for forty million Polish citizens, expresses concern for seven million Bulgarian citizens who, as they may be, are Europeans.

name: Ramona Strugariu
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, when we Romanians took to the streets in that really cold winter of 2017, I remember we felt quite lonely out there, because I was out there, and then one day, President Juncker and Vice-President Timmermans stood up and they spoke up about it, very clear and very loud. Then other voices joined them, including the one of this Parliament through a very powerful resolution, and I am grateful for that. You know why? Because it didn’t feel cold anymore and we were no longer lonely. I am here today to ask for this voice of the Commission and of the Council, and of this House, because the Bulgarian people need it. Because it matters to them, it is really important to them and we owe this to the people. It mattered fundamentally for Romania back then and for every single victory of the people and of democracy in Romania since then. I have seen powerful names in some of our political families endorsing Mr Borissov and his team and I just want to ask, do you know who you are endorsing? Because you are endorsing a carefully knitted network of people facing serious allegations of corruption, money laundering and fraud with European money and a system which is stepping on the rule of law, democracy and European values as we speak. I have seen women dragged outside by the police and pictures of children sprayed with teargas. Is this protection? Are you sure that this is what you endorse? I am calling for your voice because it does matter to the people and because this voice can make the difference between a captured state and a truly healing democracy. It happened like this in Romania, it is for the people of Bulgaria and, at the end of the day, they are the ones that matter most. (Applause)

name: Daniel Freund
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I actually went to the protests in Sofia last week. I had the opportunity to speak to a lot of people on the ground. I heard that they are fed up with the corruption in Bulgaria. I heard that the justice system is captured, and I heard that media freedom is being eroded at an alarming pace. So I can understand that Bulgarians are fed up with the speed of reform. I can understand that they say EU money, in a lot of cases, is actually making things worse, because systematically the EU funds that we give are being stolen by a corrupt elite. They are being used to cement their power or to buy up the remaining independent media.  So what are we doing as the European Union? Well, what Bulgarians see is that we are publishing another report on the rule of law. They see that Donald Tusk is fist-bumping Borisov, and a Prime Minister that has recently called protestors ‘gamblers and smugglers’. But what Bulgarians unfortunately so far are not seeing is decisive action from the European Union. The Commission is contemplating stopping the CVM; the European Council is dismantling the rule-of-law mechanism. So when I asked the Bulgarians on the ground what we should do as the European Union, the reply was unanimous: everyone I met was telling me, ‘Please stop the EU funds, because that money is not feeding hungry children. If you stop the money, you are basically taking away the caviar from corrupt oligarchs.’ So I think that is right, that is what we should do. And the EU should be with those citizens who are fighting corruption and fighting for democracy in Bulgaria.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I hope that the interruption was in all our interests and that we now have the opportunity to speak from the various places. I would like to say straight away that if this again leads to difficulties, I would ask you to be flexible enough to speak from a microphone that is working to be able to continue the debate. It depends on the content and the speech, not on the place in the European Parliament from which we are talking. But my information about the technology is that now all microphones would have to go again. I would like to thank you for your support in this difficult situation and for your flexibility. We are now continuing the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Bulgaria (2020/2793(RSP)).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, colleagues, as we have seen, and as we have shown, we tend to give everyone a say. From my microphone – we are part of the government – we gave the floor to our greatest political opponents. This says a lot about our intention and our attitude to freedom of speech, honorable President, and to different opinions. Dear, I will put out a position that will not appeal to the vast majority of you, to this left-wing majority who have gathered for a political consensus in which to make this resolution, which, by the way, is entirely and far left – both political and ideological.  We talked about the right to peaceful protests. Dear, in Bulgaria people protest, they have the right to do so, we are part of the government, but we respect their right to expression and to peaceful protest. But when we talk about the rule of law, let's give the definition of the rule of law. That means independent, quick, just justice. However, this is contrary to the draft resolution. Here I see green, extreme left, and people who deny the right of the Bulgarian Constitutional Court to make decisions. They deny any wrongdoing. This is directly contrary to the idea of the rule of law. I see texts in the draft resolution that protect the behavior of a group of people from one ethnic group who break the law. This also contradicts the idea of the rule of law – we are talking here about the case in Vojvodinovo. We're talking about the judiciary's comment at all. Politicians should not comment on the judiciary, this goes against the idea of the rule of law.  Now we go to the other topic – the topic of corruption. Well, there's something very important missing in this draft resolution. When there is talk of corruption in Bulgaria – let me not be angry with my colleagues from the Movement for Rights and Freedoms – honest, they work like this in defense of the national interest, but always in Bulgaria people think of the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, part of the Renew group. The biggest corruption scandals were related to this political group that makes the resolution. We, honorable, brought the topic of abuse into Rosenets, but we, not the Istanbul coalition, we, and these people do not dare to say the names. When you talk about corruption in Bulgaria, people always think of the Movement for Rights and Freedoms – part of Renew. These colleagues who speak out of their address should be ashamed. Corruption, but no names. Corruption has its names, and this is the Movement for Rights and Freedoms.  And now the weird stuff. Strange texts – we are supposedly talking about corruption, istanbul convention, same-sex marriage, separatism, in a second official language during the elections. Honorable, this replaces the protest. The protest is not about the Istanbul Convention, or at least I think so, that's how I see it. There are clear requests. How come it suddenly comes to you and what is actually the value of setting the topic of same-sex marriage, about the Istanbul conventions. It's something completely, completely, completely different. What I want to say to you with all due respect, knowing that you won't agree, will allow me a little respect, because I gave my word and you took my word for it. I wanted to tell you the whole thing. The Commissioner mentioned non-governmental organisations and funding. Well, yes, we want in a European country like Bulgaria to have no burden on erodogan NGOs that impose Islamism, and not to burden fake Kremlin NGOs. We are fighting against this – not for anything else and I believe that everyone will support us –no one wants green men and no one wants radical Islamism in Europe. I'm not mistaken, am I? I don't think I'm wrong. Wait, one more second. What I say, honorable, is that Bulgaria is a one-national, unitary country with one official language, and this is the Bulgarian language, and this can neither be discussed nor changed in any way by any resolution.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Although you have met me several times today, I must tell you that no one has taken the floor from you. I think it is very important that we in this Parliament do not insinuate that we are not taking the floor of someone else, but I have asked you to agree to a break. You have your word, I have not taken a word from you.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I think the importance of this motion is very obvious to anybody who saw Prime Minister Borisov and his MEPs bragging about the Commission’s rule of law report last week, claiming that it vindicated his government’s progress. And sure why wouldn’t they do that when they’ve been getting away with it for years? Playing the Commission, telling you what you want to hear, pretending to comply and then doing whatever they like and laughing all the way to the bank. And why is it happening? We heard it from the EPP – it’s because they are a pro-European party. So it doesn’t matter about the corruption. It doesn’t matter about the manipulation. Angela Merkel likes Borisov, so he’s OK. Donald Tusk says he’s one of our men. You can’t even give speaking time to the one Bulgarian opposition Member in your Group because you’re afraid of what he’ll say.  But it won’t work because the Bulgarian people are off their knees and they’ve had enough. Night after night, including tonight, for over three months they’re on the streets. They’ve been beaten, threatened with water cannons, pepper-sprayed by the police, but their resolve is stronger. They’re demanding the resignation of Borisov and new elections.  I find it astounding that people come in here and they support elections in every country outside the EU and you don’t think that Bulgarian citizens deserve the same.  This motion encapsulates the demands of the protesters. It calls for the general prosecutor in the personage of Ivan Geshev, which has been described as neither politically nor legally binding, to be dealt with, it condemns the abuse of EU funds, the staggering revelations of the Prime Minister conniving with former prosecutors to tell judges what to do, the bullying of judges, the suppression of the media, and on and on it goes!  But, do you know what? The Bulgarian citizens will deal with their government. I’m very confident of that. They’re not asking us to do that. But they do need us to stop feeding the vampires who are sucking the life blood out of the wonderful people and country. Pauperising your people, driving your young people away! Fundamental rights are just that – they’re fundamental, and the people of Bulgaria deserve them just as much as anyone else.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, very harsh words that cannot be left without comment. This parliament must not be instrumental in political propaganda of one party or another. The rule of law instrument is extremely important and we, as Democrats, stand behind the rule of law behind the effective fight against corruption.  Yes, we all want effective sentences. This is independent power. Isn't that part of the rule of law, isn't it? Democracy, mandate is also part of the rule of law. Democratic elections, preparations for them, which are scheduled for next year in March. Everyone who wants and wants change in Bulgaria should prepare for the democratic elections and lead to this change. But democratically, not with such attempts to abuse this parliament.  Of course we thank the European Commission for all the recommendations. The Bulgarian government, Bulgaria will implement all recommendations, must implement them because they are in the interest of the Bulgarian citizens. More justice, more rule of law.  But this resolution, at the expense of the report, is an absolute political nativity on the left side of this parliament. We cannot agree to this resolution, which is based on assumptions, rumors, unproven facts and, more precisely, unproven doubts about one thing or another. And of course, very interesting – I no longer see here a representative of the Socialist leadership, but their party in Bulgaria, firstly, is the most pro-Kremlin party, and secondly, on many of these topics it has a completely different opinion from the European Socialists.  I also categorically disagree that the Left will make us accept the so-called Macedonian minority. Absolutely not! Democracy, of course, always wins.

name: Katarina Barley (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the People have been taking to the streets in Bulgaria for months. They show their displeasure with corruption, the lack of separation of powers and the lack of freedom of the press in the country. The message of today's debate and the resolution we are voting on this week should therefore be: we stand by Bulgaria's civil society and support their legitimate demands for justice, transparency, the rule of law and democracy. Just a few excerpts from the Commission's annual rule-of-law monitoring report, published last week, that the fight against corruption in the country, especially in cases of high-ranking politicians, still has a lot of room for improvement. According to Eurobarometer, 80% of the population see corruption as widespread in their country. Systemic problems in the judiciary, which have been identified by the European Court of Human Rights and the Venice Commission, have still not been resolved. Under the guise of independence, a post – the Attorney General – has been created, which has a tremendous power. Symptomatic of this, the Attorney-General has described himself as an instrument in the hands of God – and so he acts. There is a lack of effective accountability mechanisms. There is also cause for concern the lack of transparency in the ownership of the Bulgarian media. According to the report, there are indications of close links between the media and political leaders. In addition, many journalists will describe political interference in the media in Bulgaria as widespread. We are also aware of cases in which journalists have been specifically threatened. The Commission should use all the instruments at its disposal to enter into this dialogue and to demand compliance with European fundamental values. Because the previous speaker had so much extra time, I would like to say this to the esteemed colleagues of the Ppe-DE: whenever we are talking about non-party governments, you are incredibly moralising. Then there is no longer any talk of respecting elections. You are calling for any resignations very quickly. Whenever it comes to your own governments, it sounds very different. Do not make the same mistake that you have made before! We are also here because you have been watching in Hungary for ten years and have still not drawn any conclusions. Do not make this mistake again with Bulgaria!

name: Илхан Кючюк (Renew).
text: – Mr President, at the beginning I want to say that this is not a debate against the Bulgarian side, it is not a debate against Bulgarian citizens. This is a debate about democracy in the Republic of Bulgaria. This discussion and subsequent resolution can only succeed if they are based on facts and not on ideological contradictions.  There is no more democratic grandstand than that of the European Parliament, because we speak 24 languages here. One of the chronic problems for the last 30 years of Bulgarian democracy, Mr. Weber, is that there is no possibility to run an election campaign in any language other than the official Bulgarian language, with the presence of an interpreter and if necessary.  If you decide to run for MEP in Bulgaria, the laws of the country allow you, the Bulgarian party GERB recognizes you or the classical right-wing in the face of the SDS decides to include you in its sheets. So far, so good. But here comes the big question. What language are you going to speak? Bulgarian electoral law says – in only one, in Bulgarian. You actually have a choice. There are two choices: one is every time you say something in German and English, you pay a €500 fine; your second choice is to run an election campaign without talking without communicating.  This is where the nationalist Dzhambazki hurts. He's in pain for something else. He said many things that are untrue in themselves, but he forgot to say about the bank of THE IRO, about the so-called passports, the gold passports. And there is a parliamentary committee here that will deal with this issue.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Do you have a point of order?

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR).
text: – Yes Mr President, this was a clear personal attack. It was personal, and a clear lie, so I will want from you and the Bureau to take a decision and to have all the records so to punish our colleague under the Rules of the European Parliament, because it was a lie, clear lie, unacceptable.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I will have your intervention checked and we will get back to you.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, addressing you today on the state of corruption and the rule of law in Bulgaria, I have a feeling of déjà vu. We have already discussed upholding democracy and fighting corruption while tens of thousands of EU citizens protest on the streets. Yet again, we are noting with concern the high level of corruption, the degradation of judicial independence and the lack of media freedom in an EU Member State. Yet again, our response to their continued cries for support remains too weak, too little and too late.  Commissioners, we have complimented you, and we want to compliment you, on the quality of the annual rule of law report. It seems to me that we have the same long-term priorities. However, in order to demonstrate that we are fully committed to the rule of law right now, we need to see concrete action resulting from this exercise. We cannot fight an open fire only with an inventory of what started the fire. Have we not learned anything from the cases of Hungary and Poland?  The annual report just published shows significant deficiencies in Bulgaria across a number of areas, but most notably in the use of public funds. The Commission needs to act on these findings. As a bare minimum we need to maintain the cooperation and verification mechanism, and on this we disagree with the Commission because no other instrument exists at the moment to challenge the situation and fight the corruption.
