name: Елена Йончева (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today the voice of Bulgarian citizens is already clearly heard throughout Europe. This is a voice that calls for the immediate return of the principles of the rule of law and democracy in the country.  Mr. Borisov, for more than a decade in power, allowed certain persons and circles to benefit from Bulgaria's membership of the European Union at the expense of the Bulgarian people. Year after year, his rule leads to more and more (words are not heard), more abuse of power, more poverty and more collapse of media freedom.  That's why we say today – come on! And the resolution that we will vote on this week for Bulgaria, this is a resolution for ... (words are not heard). We insist on a country where politicians focus on reforms where the human dignity and the right of every group in society are respected.  Today I also address the German Presidency with one question – how long will the Council be silent? I also turn to the Commission because it will depend on what it does, whether Bulgaria will continue on this authoritarian path. Today, Bulgaria's pain is already a pain of the entire European Union.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Mr President, I believe that we are once again witnessing a worrying precedent this evening. We can, and this is undeniable, not agree with the Bulgarian Prime Minister, that is a fact. But some here are once again seeking to use the fundamental question of the rule of law to reflect political disagreements. The question of the rule of law is: can Bulgarian citizens demonstrate freely? The answer is yes, colleagues, you were at these events. Does the media ignore criticism of the government? The answer is no, we all know that. Is there political pluralism in Bulgaria? Of course, yes, the President is even from a different camp than the Prime Minister, and he plays a significant role in the ongoing protests. The Commission itself has just highlighted the undeniable progress that has been made by Bulgaria. Of course, much remains to be done, but if the Bulgarians are not satisfied with their government, they can, they must, they will say it themselves in the elections that will come and if they are satisfied then they will choose to renew it. Colleagues, democracy is too important for us to choose to enter into an electoral process and take part in what is akin to a form of manipulation of electoral freedom, I believe that the rule of law of course goes through this, first it is our responsibility.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, however this debate ends, the name of our country will be tarnished. I am a member of this parliament with a mandate of five years, but I am Bulgarian as long as I am alive, and as such I ask you: Is this what you promised your constituents a year ago? Who stops people in Bulgaria from protesting, tell me?  Every day for the last three months we have evidence to the contrary and no one claims that this government is absolutely sinless and has solved all the problems of the transition. But to stand up in the European Parliament and say that children are being gassed in Bulgaria – for God's sake, you have to have some boundaries! We all want an independent judiciary, but it is the product of a common effort, a common effort in which you do not participate. Moreover, this will not work by replacing one government with another. This parliament cannot be used for party battles. Worse still, for the aspiration of one to stand in power without being elected to it. Any opposition that insists that a legitimately elected government withdraws just days before the regular elections itself admits that it does not have the strength to win such elections.  Dear, governments come and go, but people stay. And such debates will not win you the election, nor will they give you 10 years of confidence to govern. We'il be fine when we stop taking the problems out and start solving them ourselves. We give her a hand to work with each one. Bulgaria above all!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. –  Mr President, honourable Members, I think it was quite a symbolic thing that we had a technical problem with the microphones while speaking about democracy and freedom of speech and pluralism of media, because we saw that simply speaking, the more microphones we have the better the debate is. So thank you very much, this was a very good debate again about a very serious and important topic relating to the rule of law, in this case the rule of law relating to one concrete country which is Bulgaria.  As I said at the beginning, we will continue working on the cooperation and verification mechanism because simply there is still unfinished business, there are still things to be done, and CVM was never just ticking the boxes, because, at the Commission which followed very closely the progress of the reforms, we wanted to see tangible results and a sustainable, positive effect on the Bulgarian judiciary and on the Bulgarian system for fighting corruption and organised crime. And I have to add one thing, we continue the CVM also while seeing that there was quite strong interest from the Bulgarian people that there is this work continuing, that due to the fact that there is still very low trust in the Bulgarian judiciary and fight against corruption, many Bulgarian people, according to many surveys, gave us the message, ‘Continue and accomplish the work properly. We want to see the job done’. And this is what we are doing now. And next to that we started to work on the rule of law mechanism which Didier Reynders spoke about before and I think that it is important that now we work in those two tracks. We believe that we can achieve those tangible results, but it requires very good cooperation with the Bulgarian authorities.  I want to mention one more thing, soon we will see the European Public Prosecutor’s Office starting to function and Bulgaria is one of the countries which joined the EPPO, which was very active over the process of negotiations and which is now working towards the full functioning of the EPPO, the good representation of Bulgaria in the structures of the EPPO, and the EPPO will be one of the very serious and I believe useful contributions of the EU in helping the Member States to fight against corruption and crime relating to EU money.  So I’m ready to continue working with the Bulgarian authorities both on CVM and the continuation of the work following the rule of law report. Bulgaria will be among the first five countries which will be debated at the Council, and I believe that together we can achieve results, which will also increase the trust of Bulgarian people, because all the reforms, all the efforts have to be done in Bulgaria not because Brussels wants it, but because the Bulgarian people deserve it.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I don’t want to add so much after what was said by Vice-President Jourová, but just to insist on the fact that of course we have the opportunity to take actions. As just said, at the end of the year, beginning of next year, we’ll start with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, so it’s a real action from all the institutions together, and now we will have the possibility to organise prosecutions after investigations, at EU level, so it’s a good instrument to fight against these kinds of crime at the different levels in the European Union.  We have the CVM, of course, but we also have the rule of law report, and in the rule of law report I have said we have positive developments but also we have real concern. I don’t want to repeat what I’ve said on the different chapters also about Bulgaria, like all the Member States. I just want to insist on one point. As Michael Roth said on behalf of the German Presidency, we will have a discussion in November about five Member States, including Bulgaria, because it’s very important to analyse the situation not in general, but country by country, Member State by Member State. And I repeat what I have said in the discussions in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs: we are open to come and discuss with Parliament the situation in all the different Member States, including Bulgaria. It’s the best way to have a fair analysis of the situation and really explain what it is possible to do with the actual tools that we have in our toolbox concerning the rule of law in Bulgaria like in all Member States.  But it’s not true to say there are words and papers but no action. Again, it will be very important in the fight against corruption to start with the EPPO next year, but we will use all the tools at our disposal in Bulgaria, like in all the Member States, but please, maybe it will be fine to organise a debate on the basis of the rule of law report on each and every Member State, including Bulgaria.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thank you, also for the opportunity to take part in this debate. People who peacefully demonstrate for our European values deserve our respect, sympathy and solidarity – in Bulgaria and in all other parts of Europe. I would like to single out a point that one Member made here by saying that this debate here would tarnish him, his country would be tarnished. I believe that this argument touches on the heart of the problem. These debates may be painful, they may be problematic for some reasons for political reasons, but they are necessary. I say this as a citizen of a country where yesterday there was an attack on a man of Jewish faith – in a liberal and cosmopolitan city. We have a massive increase in anti-Semitic violence in my own country, and I cannot regard it as a stain on Germany when we face up to this painful discussion. Minorities, be they religious, sexual, ethnic, cultural, deserve their place throughout the European Union. If there are problems – exclusion, discrimination, oppression – then this must be addressed without it being seen as interfering in the internal circumstances of another country and without it being seen as a disadvantage for the country in which it is concerned. That is why it is so important – and therefore also 'thank you' to all of you for this debate – that we impose a review of the rule of law on all the Member States of the European Union. I recognise that the partners in Bulgaria have very quickly also declared their willingness to actively participate in the Rule of Law Check in the first round. The debates and arguments that you have also provided, honourable Members – sometimes more positive and more benevolent, sometimes a little more critical – will certainly also be included in the Council's very open debate, scheduled for November. The Council, honourable Members, is not silent. The Council, like the Commission, as well as the European Parliament, assumes its responsibility to strengthen the rule of law. Once again, this is one of the key priorities of the German EU Presidency.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Roth, thank you very much. Finally, in a difficult debate, may I just say once again that justice is united and is the basis for reform, protects the citizen. Law does not divide. Perhaps it is a beautiful symbol of what we have seen here today that on the one hand the microphones have not gone a few times. In other words, not everything is in order everywhere. But together we decided to interrupt briefly, and then again to make sure that everyone and everyone should have their voice in their place. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Wednesday and the final vote on Thursday. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen Avram (S&D)
text: in writing. – Although there were obvious and loud signs of the deterioration of the political and democratic situation in Bulgaria, due to unfortunate political interests, the European Parliament took months to finally have a debate on this issue. And even so, it was too brief to cover in depth the complexity of the events in Sofia. One of my main concerns is the abuse on the Bulgarian journalists, having been persecuted by the Government, in ways incompatible with the basic principles of our Union, being denied access to crucial decision-making forums and being targeted and smeared by hateful campaigns of denigration. This is why, I salute this resolution regarding the Rule of Law and Fundamental Right in Bulgaria which calls, rightly so, for the protection of the journalists, the watchdogs of our societies, and asks the Bulgarian Government to protect them and their freedom of expression, to open investigations on the acts of violence against members of the media and to ensure that authorities respect the freedom of the press and the vital work of the journalists.

name: Radan Kanev (PPE)
text: in writing. – Being not granted the floor for this debate, I am addressing you under Rule 171(11) of our Rules of Procedure. I am specifically addressing my EPP colleagues to carefully consider the situation in Bulgaria and the importance of the debate, not only for the Bulgarian citizens and European taxpayers, but for the future of the EU. This debate may easily slip into pre-election partisanship. To avoid that risk, I am calling on you to focus on the real problem, and to consider it in the context of the other two major debates we are holding today – on the rule of law mechanism and on the conditionality clause. Our problem is simple, yet most serious: there is a mafia takeover of the judiciary and media in a Member State. You may support the government in Bulgaria, or you may not. These are sometimes challenging political choices. If you trust the government, you may try to help it get rid of dangerous dependencies – a futile, but noble effort. But there is no such choice as denying the truth, neither staying idle, when the rule of law is trampled in a European country. This is not a choice, but complicity.

name: Guido Reil (ID)
text: Writing. – Parliament criticises the lack of the rule of law and fundamental rights in Bulgaria and is concerned that corruption has spread to the highest levels of government. In contrast, Parliament supported some time ago the Commission's recommendation to abolish the cooperation and control procedure for Bulgaria, the aim of which was to review the rule of law and fundamental rights, thereby preventing the situation that has now arisen. After the collapse of communism, a corrupt, oligarchic elite took power in Bulgaria. Accession to the EU has only led to more corruption. Much of the EU's money from the various Structural Funds has gone into the pockets of corrupt officials among the political and economic elite from the outset. All the warnings on the eve of accession have not been heard. As a result, tens of thousands of Bulgarians have left their country to flee corruption and poverty. For example, Bulgarian nurses work throughout Europe, but clinics in Bulgaria are underfunded and suffering from staff shortages. The EUROPEAN Parliament has forfeited the right to get upset. It has accepted the devastating development of Bulgaria's eye sight.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the presentation of the Council's position on the draft general budget for the financial year 2021 (2020/2697(RSP)). I do not need to repeat the communication that this debate does not allow for a blue card or spontaneous speech.

name: Bettina Hagedorn
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr John, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased to present to you today the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021. I would like to begin by highlighting a number of points, in particular the challenge that the COVID-19 pandemic is all facing us. This pandemic has a significant impact on the procedure for establishing the EU budget for 2021. We must reach an agreement on the 2021 budget together within the shortest possible time and with limited opportunities for physical meetings. In addition, our three institutions are discussing the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2021-2027 in a different context, and the outcome of this consultation is a crucial factor in drawing up a budget for 2021. I would like to stress that, in these turbulent times, we are fully aware of our responsibilities as the arm of the budgetary authority. We are ready to meet the expectations of EU citizens and to establish a balanced and forward-looking budget for 2021. Against this background, we must carefully consider what taxpayers' contributions are spent on in the EU. As always, the Council will call for prudence and budgetary discipline. As the current pandemic shows, this approach is now more important than ever, because we need to have sufficient room for manoeuvre to deal with the as yet unknown challenges and risks that we may expect next year. The German Presidency will do its utmost to reach agreement for next year on an EU budget that will take the EU forward, focusing on the Union's budgetary objectives and the benefits for our citizens. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Let me now go into more detail about the Council's position. We started our work immediately after the Presentation of the Commission's proposal on 24 June. In the absence of agreement on the medium-term financial framework 2021-2027, the Commission's draft budget was based on its own proposal for the 2021-2027 MFF, which was last updated on 27 May. The July European Council reached agreement on the medium-term financial framework for the next seven years, but this differs from the basis on which the Commission based the draft budget for 2021. As the Commission has not presented a revised draft budget for 2021, the Council has drawn up its position as follows. Firstly, operational expenditure. The Council accepted in principle the contributions proposed by the Commission in the draft budget for 2021, but in an adapted form to take account of the guidelines of the European Council. The Council is aware that this method may ignore the specific expenditure profiles of some programmes and will therefore also reassess its position as soon as the Commission presents relevant information in connection with the letter of amendment. Incidentally, the Council expects the letter of amendment before 31 October, hoped to have sufficient time to examine it before our joint conciliation period.  As far as administrative expenditure is concerned, a two-pronged approach has been adopted. Firstly, the Council has consolidated the staffing levels of all the institutions except those of the European Parliament, of course, at the current level. Secondly, the Council has reduced contributions for missions and meeting costs in line with the changes in the working methods of all the institutions caused by COVID-19, but the European Parliament is also excluded from this measure. Let me explain in more detail some of the key points of the Council's position. Firstly, the Council has made an arithmetic correction of the amounts proposed by the Commission for 2021 in terms of commitments and payment appropriations. This applies to all programmes for which a different contribution is now foreseen compared to the Commission's MFF proposal of 27 May. The Council's second measure is an increase of EUR 3.6 billion in payment appropriations. The aim is to offset the budgetary impact of an increase in the pre-financing rate of certain programmes from 1% to 2% from 1 January 2021. Thirdly, the Council adjusted the payment for REACT-EU and cancelled it for the Solvency Assistance Instrument after it was decided not to amend the current MFF 2014-2020. Finally, a budget line for the new Brexit reserve. This approach gives rise to a Council position, which provides for AN amount of EUR 162.9 billion in commitments and EUR 164.8 billion in appropriations for payments. These amounts ensure a very good development of expenditure. Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, Commissioner, Mr John, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by saying that I believe that today's debate will usher in a series of constructive and open discussions. These talks will enable us to reach a balanced and forward-looking compromise. We must not deviate from our common objectives and we must demonstrate our strong commitment to Europe. I am convinced that we can agree on a budget for 2021 within the jointly agreed period. Thank you for your attention.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly I would like to congratulate the German Presidency on reaching an agreement with the Member States on the draft budget 2021 position. We understand that this is a provisional position, which more or less mechanically translates the European Council’s July MFF agreement into the annual budget.  I cannot stress enough how vital it is to reach a political agreement on the MFF as soon as possible. Based on this, I understand the Council will re-evaluate its position once an agreement has been reached with Parliament and once the Commission has updated the draft budget proposal in accordance with the amending letter. Let me assure you that we will deliver the proposal for the amending letter as soon as possible after the MFF agreement, but there needs to be an agreement first. Prolonging the current framework is absolutely no substitute. Contingency arrangements would prolong uncertainty and entail further difficulties.  The Commission will of course continue to act as an honest broker to facilitate a compromise. We will work day and night if necessary to bring these negotiations to a successful outcome.  As regards Parliament’s reading of the budget, we take good note of the positions expressed in Parliament’s guidelines and proposals for amendments. The Commission will respond to Parliament’s and the Council’s proposals for amendments in detail in its executability letter, which will be presented ahead of the conciliation procedure. On our timeline for the draft budget 2021 negotiations, let me emphasise that this year we have virtually no room for manoeuvre in our calendar and, of course, the prerequisite is the MFF agreement. Due to the delay in the MFF procedure, the Conciliation Committee cannot be convened until 17 November and, as usual, we have 21 days (which means until 7 December) to reach an agreement. I trust we all understand that this leaves no margin for failure. The agreement on the draft budget 2021 has to be found within these 21 days if we want to start 2021 with a budget in place. There will be simply no time to present a second proposal for a draft budget.  We will need to work together more actively and constructively. Both Parliament and the Council have already expressed the sincere wish to cooperate and find an agreement. I am thus confident that this is possible and I see no reason why we should fail. Our citizens rely on us to find effective solutions in this time of crisis. The 2021 budget will make a vital contribution to supporting our people and our pandemic relief activities, as well as the many other sectors that the Union budget supports. The recent rise in COVID-19 infections across Europe proves more than anything else the need to find an agreement on the MFF and ensure a functioning budget as of 1 January 2021.

name: Pierre Larrouturou
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, you know, we cannot accept the budget you are proposing for Europe. We cannot accept the cuts that the Council has decided to make in health, employment, research or climate. So how to unlock the negotiation, how to reach a win-win agreement, how to find the means to finance the 15 priorities set by Parliament on 23 July. The solution is to move forward in a very concrete and very fast way on own resources. The Council has already accepted the plastic contribution. That is a very good thing, but it will bring in $7 billion a year, and that money should go down if people use less plastic. That is why we must also move very quickly and very concretely on the other five own resources that the European Parliament is asking for and in particular on the financial transaction tax. It was the Barroso Commission in 2011 that proposed the tax directive and did the impact assessment. Everything is ready for it to be put in place. Of all the own resources requested by Parliament, it is the most technically and politically mature, and the Barroso Commission said it could bring in 81 billion euros in 2020. Brexit is losing 30% of the base, but the financial markets are doing very well. Despite Brexit, despite the economic crisis, the financial transaction tax can bring in 50 billion euros a year.  Fifty billion each year is 50 times more than a digital tax, even if it is also a very good idea. With Next Generation EU, Germany will have to repay just over 100 billion euros. If all the common debt were repaid by the FTT, Germany could keep its $100 billion and turn to it for health and pensions. If Parliament insists so much that the FTT will arrive in 2024, (this date is still one of the sticking points of the trilogue) it is to avoid falling back into recession. For by 2024, after a three-year influx of money thanks to Next Generation EU, the Member States will have somewhat forgotten the constraints. And if every country has to respect the traditional deficit rules, and if the Union returns to a very small MFF, we will fall back into recession. That is why Parliament wants the FTT for 2024, not 2026, because if we have two years of budgetary hole, we are very, very likely to fall back into recession, which would be dramatic for the recovery.  On the other hand, if we come to an agreement on the FTT in the next few weeks and if we can count on it for four years, it will give us an additional $200 billion for the entire MFF. And with this $200 billion, we will be able to raise the ceilings for 2021 and find funding as early as 2021 for Parliament's fifteen priorities.  So we can unlock the MFF negotiation and the negotiation in 2021 at the same time. Everything is ready and the German Presidency has said that this is one of its priorities. So what are we waiting for? You say that you are ready to work day and night, Commissioner, Michael Roth has also reiterated this earlier, so we have to move forward, everything is ready.  I am the budget rapporteur. I have already said this and I will say it again: in conscience: I will not be able to vote on the next budget if we do not get an agreement on the 50 billion more each year for climate, health and employment thanks to the FTT. We have to move forward, we have to unblock the negotiation, that's why I wrote to you to propose a specific meeting on the issue of the FTT to unlock the negotiation in 2021 and the CFP negotiation. A meeting whose purpose would be to make real progress on this request from Parliament: to tax speculation in order to have more money for our fifteen priorities. I would like to finish talking about our ambition. If we have a great ambition for Europe, a great ambition for our children, we must have a large budget. That is why I suggest that we really get back to work without delay, starting this week. Let's review this week to move forward and unblock the negotiation. It is together that we will build this ambition and it is together that we can finance it!

name: Olivier Chastel
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, as we know this 2021 budget is particularly important because it is, by definition, the first of the next multi-year financial framework. The decision deadlines, Pierre Larrouturou has just mentioned, are extremely tight and the European Parliament does not have to take responsibility for this. We decided our position almost two years ago, in November 2018. However, it was not until 21 July this year that the Council took a position in favour of European solidarity. It is now a question of realising this solidarity for 2021 by allocating a sufficient budget to ensure the functioning of structural reforms and the effectiveness of the Union's policies. We cannot disappoint our citizens, who have been hit by an unprecedented double health and economic crisis, with European programmes at a discount. We need an ambitious 2021 budget, which is able to support sustainable and resilient [missing passage] and which charts the way to European sovereignty in terms of health, digital, industrial and security.  The Council has chosen an arithmetic approach to the amounts proposed by the Commission for 2021 for several programmes based on the position of the European Council and without identifying any real priorities. Cuts to the European Union's flagship programmes, such as climate, digital, health or research, are already undermining the very foundations of this recovery. Citizens are waiting for the European Union to offer them an exit from the crisis with collective and solidarity projects and only political will would lead to a fair and balanced ambitious agreement on the next multi-year financial framework. We very much hope that such an agreement will be reached before the end of October, so that the Commission can send us its amending letter as soon as possible, which will update its position on the 2021 budget. Parliament has not chosen to work under the pressure of the time imposed on us by the Council. We urge him to review his position as soon as possible so that we can adjust ours before the start of the conciliation which opens on 17 November and for 21 days of conciliation in a constructive, open spirit, with frank and honest exchanges so that we can meet the legitimate expectations of European citizens. We must be able to obtain as soon as possible stabilised financial amounts that enable us to identify European decisions that bring about sustainable investment and human cooperation at the service of European citizens.

name: Bettina Hagedorn
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I thank you for this start in an interesting and, I am convinced, fruitful exchange of ideas. Today's debate shows that, despite differences of opinion on individual points, we share a common objective, which is to establish a sound budget for 2021.  Let me respond to the concerns expressed by you as follows: many of the objections that reach us on the Council's position relate to the Council's approach to drawing up its Position on the 2021 draft budget. This arithmetic approach by the Council is linear and does not yet take into account the possibly faster implementation plans of certain programmes, such as the Neighbourhood, Development Cooperation and International Cooperation Instrument. The Council is ready, as I said at the beginning of today's debate, to clarify these technical details in the context of conciliation on the basis of the Commission's pending letter of amendment. We have reduced staff expenditure in line with our approach to stabilising staffing levels; we believe that the increases proposed by various institutions can be achieved by redeployment. I would like to stress that these savings would have no effect on individual salaries, for example. With a provisional reduction of 140 posts at the Commission, we are open to the Commission's proposals. On the question of how to meet the additional needs of the decentralised agencies, taking into account our position on stabilising the overall staffing, we believe that the reduction of 10% in travel and mission costs is justified in itself by the fact that there will be fewer meetings, conferences and other events requiring a physical presence, not only in 2020, but also in 2021. Because we will certainly stick to what we are doing in videoconferencing for a while. Parliament has asked us to adapt the nomenclature of the budget, particularly in heading 6. It may be a very technical issue, but the budgetary structure does indeed touch on the core of the role that we, the European Parliament and the Council, have as budgetary authority. We will examine all the official proposals of the European Parliament as we prepare the Council's mandate for our final conciliation. Let me now also briefly address the questions raised about the multiannual financial framework and the own resources system. As I said at the beginning, our three institutions are discussing these issues in a different context. The Council will shortly adopt a new own resources decision, which will include a new own resources category based on plastic packaging waste. The European Council also invited the Commission to submit proposals for a CO2 boundary equalisation system and a digital levy in the first half of 2021. Finally, in the course of the next multiannual financial framework, the Union will work towards the introduction of other own resources, including a financial transaction tax. The Council's position does not address the impact of the Next Generation EU instrument on Union programmes, as the amounts to be used for expenditure are external, dedicated revenue. However, we share the European Parliament's view that the budgetary authority should have a greater role to play in terms of external, dedicated revenue in order to ensure adequate control and participation in the use of this revenue. As you know, we are currently working together on this. Let me conclude by saying that I look forward to the European Parliament's position on the 2021 budget. Many of these points are certainly taken up and thus the subject of conciliation. We can count on the Commission – John – to act as an honest broker to bridge possible differences between our positions and propose balanced compromise solutions. Europe as a whole needs a budget that meets the needs of its citizens and strengthens confidence in a better future, especially in these difficult times. I am confident that, with full commitment on the part of the European Parliament, the Commission and our stake, we can reach an agreement in good time. Thank you again for your attention.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. I’d like to inform Members that, due to the partial unavailability of interpreters from Malta and Ireland because of the travel limitations, there will only be passive interpretation from Maltese and Gaelic to other languages guaranteed from 8.00 to 10.30. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Marco Zanni (ID)
text: in writing. Once again, this year, we are debating a disconsistetable budget, which does not provide concrete answers to the real problems of citizens, even in the face of the terrible crisis produced by the Coronavirus pandemic. Italy, which I remember being an important net contributor to the EU budget, does not need to hear the age-old slogans that have been repeated for years now, thanks to which this Europe seems perfect at any time, when in reality it is not at all.  How can we persevere with the usual mistakes that I have been seeing for years now? The usual administrative waste, the same waste of taxpayers' money, the same promises of solidarity that are not kept. We are discussing a budget which, for a change, shows no sign of rationalising its expenditure. European companies are closing down because of the current crisis and, in the meantime, the costs of this Parliament are rising.  Not to mention the renewed support for Turkey, for which EU funds are still provided despite the fact that in recent weeks it has once again demonstrated how much it does not respect the Eastern Mediterranean Member States.  The institutions' budget is nothing more than the EU's political strategy in figures. And looking at the proposed numbers every year, I am increasingly confirming how much this Europe needs to be reviewed, along with its priorities.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on women in decision making on company boards, including the state of play on the directive on improving the gender balance among non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges and related measures (2020/2808(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that for all the debates of this part—session there will be no catch—the—eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I am grateful to you for being able to take part in this debate too, because gender equality and gender equality are one of the priorities of the German EU Presidency. We have decided to focus on two main priorities in the short presidency. This is the still massive injustice in the labour market with regard to the gender pay gap, which averages 14.8% in the European Union – well over 20% in my own country. This is incompatible with our notions of equal pay for equal work in the same place. Another point is the still dramatically high level of violence against women. Here, too, we want to support initiatives in this way. And that leads me to the issue that has been in the Council since 2017, without any substantial progress. In 2017, under the Maltese Presidency of the Council of Commissioner Dalli, the last attempt was made to reach an agreement on Women on Board. We all share a common interest here: the glass ceiling must be broken. We have made considerable progress here in the political sphere, but here too we are still a long way from gender parity in parliaments. We have 38% of women here in the European Parliament. That is not enough, because half of our society is women who have a natural share of representativeness. We are dealing with two dangerous forms of segregation. One is horizontal segregation and the other is vertical segregation. There are still industries in our society where men are in charge. The proportion of women in management positions is significantly under-represented, particularly in the fields of technology and the economy, but also in science and the media sector. And then we have another segregation in such a way that men are not prepared to take responsibility in certain areas, which, incidentally, are generally paid significantly less. This is family care, it is the health and care sector, where men still play little role in fact. That is why the gender pay gap is so important, because it is usually also occupations that are paid significantly less. And men often say: No, we don't want to get involved. You know the position of my government. However, I am not standing here as a representative of the Federal Government, but I am representing the Council here. That is why I assure you all once again that, despite the controversial discussions in my own government, we see ourselves as an honest broker, especially as I can tell you that legal requirements make a positive difference. After all, we have introduced a quota in the area of business leaders, which has at least led to a third of the positions on supervisory boards being filled by women. This is a step in the right direction. Unfortunately, the proportion of boards where there is no legal regulation is still well below 10%.  In this respect, I hope that we can now once again take a major step forward by means of intensive consultation and also by supporting Commissioner Dalli's commitment, so that the European Union can make it clear here too that it can set benchmarks at international level on issues of gender equality and gender equality. And we, as the German Presidency of the Council, will fulfil our responsibilities here as brokers and as bridge builders in the Council.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you, honourable Members of Parliament, for putting this important topic of women in corporate decision-making on the agenda today. I am grateful for your continued strong support to our fight for gender equality, non-discrimination and inclusion for all EU citizens. I’m equally grateful for the support you are showing these days on moving the Commission’s proposal for the directive on gender balance on corporate boards of listed companies forward. We urgently need progress on this file, now more than ever. Progress regarding female representation on corporate boards and business leadership positions remains very slow and uneven across the EU. The figures from the Gender Equality Index of the European Institute for Gender Equality are of concern. They clearly show that we need urgent action. On average, only around 28% of board members of the largest publicly-listed companies registered in the EU are women, and women still only account for 8% of CEOs. These are not the numbers of a gender-equal Europe, nor does it reflect the talent available. Beyond being a matter of equality or lack thereof, this is a clear waste of human capital. Evidence shows that a broad range of talents and skills in the boardroom contributes to better decisions, better corporate governance, and public trust in business. This is what drives economic growth. Despite their capabilities and educational achievements, women continue to struggle against long-held and systemic entry barriers into corporate boards and leadership positions. We need to ask why. One major obstacle is the lack of transparency in the selection process and qualification criteria, and this is what the Commission’s proposal aims to address. I must be clear again on this point. The Commission is not imposing binding gender quotas. What the proposal does instead is to require the establishment of transparent procedures for the selection of board positions in the largest EU-listed companies to address the gender imbalance. Such an approach places qualification and merit of candidates as the main criterion for board membership. With this approach, which places qualification and merit upfront, it is hard to understand why we are not managing to adopt this directive. I regret to say that, after 8 years, we still are waiting for a general approach in Council. At the same time, this Commission has put equality high on the political agenda. The Commission is striving to lead by example. For the first time in its history we are closest to a gender-balanced college. The Commission has also just adopted new measures to reinforce gender equality at all levels of management within the Commission. The objective to unblock the negotiations is one of my core tasks. It is also a priority. It is also a priority action in the gender equality strategy for 2020-25, which we adopted earlier this year. The Commission has been engaged in discussions with opponents and supporters of the initiative. Our message is clear: the adoption of the directive would represent a major step forward in our fight for gender equality in Europe. It would send a strong, clear message to the EU citizens and beyond: the European economy makes the best use of all its talent. Some voices try to depict this proposal as a burden on companies. Experience shows that it is not. On the contrary, it is a tool bringing concrete benefits to European and national economies. I count on your continued support on this file and to make Europe a continent where women have the same opportunities as men to reach their full potential.

name: Angelika Niebler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is good that this question has been addressed to the Council today. I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mrs Regner, who has also taken this initiative. Gender equality, gender equality, this is one of the most important issues we have here in the European Union. Egalitarianism is one of our central principles in the European Union. And when I see how the situation of women in the Member States has developed, I can only say that there is a great deal to be done.  The directive is highly symbolic. Of course, the directive alone is not enough, and I believe that the minimum set must also change. But the directive also has its significance. I do not believe that the situation of women has improved, especially in the times of Corona, but on the contrary, it has rather deteriorated. When I see that in my own country, the occupations of women – the professions in which many women are – have been classified as systemically important. Without all our women in the clinics, in the nursing homes, in schools, in the daycare centres, in the supermarkets and and, ladies and gentlemen, we would not have been able to get through the crisis so far. Appreciation was there, but that was it. But that is not enough, of course. There must be a jolt through society that women also have equal opportunities here and are equal. I have a question for the Commission, because it has been taken up that this directive has been on hold in the Council for many years. I know from the debates that we had in the Committee on Legal Affairs for months that the issue of the legal basis was one of the issues – in addition to the political debate – that many people – including Germany – have said that this is a violation of subsidiarity. I would therefore ask again: what has been done, including on the part of the Commission, to clear up the legal basis here again? Because, I believe, this is also the nucleus around which everything revolves.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, women are an asset, an asset in every company when they are also on the board. The most successful companies are those with the most diverse board of directors. Yet there are still too few, and we know voluntary measures are not enough. We need binding measures. We need binding quotas – they are key. Only then will women have a fair chance. We have the newest European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE) data from June 2020. Countries with a binding quota have about 10% more women on boards than in countries with only voluntary measures – and that’s what we see. And countries which did nothing, they have almost no progress. And yet we know, for so many years already, this ‘women on boards’ directive has been blocked in the Council. And so therefore, we say: we don’t accept, in the European Parliament,  this snail’s pace. We need to speed up in order really to have equal chances. Therefore my question to the Council: what are you doing? What are you really doing? Because we want to progress. And we see it in these days, the Council also nominates again two men for the European Central Bank. Okay, this is another issue. But we really have to speed up, so please take this on board. We, the European Parliament, we don’t give up. (Applause),

name: Samira Rafaela
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the glass ceiling exists, or perhaps we are now saying better: the concrete ceiling exists. For years, the Women on Board directive has not worked because it is stuck in the Council. Member States, including my own, the Netherlands, continue to refuse to vote in favour of this directive. Fear of the principle of subsidiarity – always an easy excuse – while giving The Member States and businesses a lot of leeway to make this directive a success as they come into being.  The 40% criterion in the Women on Board directive is not much to ask. What is wrong with a proportional distribution of responsibilities between men and women? Where it is a given for men, we have to quantify it in numbers for women. We say to women: you are good, but no more than 33%. We want equal opportunities, including at the tables on the boards of directors. And for those Member States that do not want to cooperate, it really does: figures do not lie, and you are not there yet. The corona crisis shows how indispensable the leadership and commitment of women on the front line but also in top positions is. More than ever, it has become clear that we are needed at the table, but not on the chair at that table. Young women who are now growing up in Europe need role models, role models who show them that they can also reach the top. But they also need to trust that there are enough female leaders to secure their future. The systematic exclusion of women in top positions within companies that affect our future on a daily basis is downright stupid.  In the European Union, we are making it an important spearhead: equality between men and women. But the Member States are afraid: afraid to misrepresent national political parties, afraid of supposedly losing voters and afraid to listen to their own representation in the EU. All that on women's backs.  Improving the economic position of women and increasing the influence of women can be achieved by agreeing to the Women on Board directive. Be part of the solution and vote for the directive.

name: Christine Anderson (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Each company acts in a way that maximizes its profit. This also applies, of course, to vacancies. So if a woman is more suitable for a job than a man, then it is in the very best interests of the company to hire that woman and not the man. But the Commission does not rely on that. Instead, the Commission is now harassing the Member States with its highly embarrassing politically correct quota for women. But why is the demand limited to women's quotas in management positions? Why do we not also demand quotas for women in construction workers, lorry drivers or sewer workers? No wonder more and more companies are migrating to developing and emerging economies, where they can make business-friendly decisions free of ideological nonsense. At the end of the day, the market will regulate what the Commission is trying to force. If, in the end, men and women are equally unemployed, they can establish their gender parity in the area of transfers. There is certainly something in the context of EU unemployment insurance. No, it remains the case: women's quotas are state-celebrated envable sexism. A state-enforced quota of women reflects what women's movements of the past have rightly fought against – namely, the image of women that women seem to be too weak to succeed in the job, and therefore need the support of the state. Your call for quotas for women does not help women. On the contrary, you are shamefully revealing your pathetic, condescending, presumptuous and patronising attitude towards women. The chauvinists and machos of this world let the champagne corks pop. The EU Commission, led by a woman, officially confirms the chauvinistic image of women – well!

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, my colleague Manon Aubry just pointed out to me that in such an important debate for gender equality we have, like, 25 speakers, and only Mr Roth and I are men in that debate. I think this is really shameful and I would like to say that that we need women on board, but I think we need more men on board in those debates as well. Having said so, I think that we absolutely need to unblock that directive: it’s about time. We have had time since 2012 for this, and I would like to say that now we also have the experience of countries that have established those kinds of quotas and that it has actually worked. Look at Norway: Norway has at the moment, thanks to quotas, 35% of women on boards, while in some Member States we don’t reach even 10%. So now it’s about time that we do that. Also I think that in order to put gender equality at the top of the agenda when a lot of women are suffering inequalities now during the pandemic, EU institutions need to send a clear message that we take that seriously. I know that the Presidency is committed to unblock that, and I know that around 18 Member States are already convinced. I can only say to the German Presidency: please try to unblock that file and make that file a reality by the end of the year.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Dalli, why are you here today? Is it on your merits or do we have to think it's about meeting a quota? When women joined the labour market, she was free to choose the professions. Eight out of ten European toilets are women. Is this disproportionate? Do we now invent a quota to promote male presence? This would lack common sense. From the European institutions they threaten us with sanctions, tough legislation, to keep us under control and teledied in their ideological objectives. But they don't land on people's real worries. The problems are different in each country, in each company or in each family. They cannot be fixed by pre-established quotas, which is also proven not to work. If you want to help us, if you want to help real women, don't consider us statistics or require us to imitate men. Value us for who we are, women, mothers and excellent professionals. We don't need you to discriminate against anyone so we can shine.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of gender equality in economic decision-making is now more topical than ever. It is not only a demand for social justice, but it is a vital element of the economic recovery that Europe so badly needs. But it is obvious that women will not appear on the boards automatically and the national voluntary measures taken to date in some Member States are not enough to make a difference in the European business community.  It is indeed oxymoron that, while official European data show that European companies perform better when there is high gender representation on boards, women still make up about a quarter of non-executive directors and only 8% are female CEOs in the European Union. That is why we must continue to press together, the European Parliament and the Commission, to overcome the impasse in the Council and to adopt immediately the proposed directive on the participation of women on the boards of companies, which has been frozen since 2013.

name: Arba Kokalari (PPE).
text: – Mr President and colleagues, I would like to begin by congratulating mr That women and men should have the same choice and freedom to shape their own life and their future, yes, that is the basis of a democratic and equal society, but unfortunately we are not there today. Yet the gender debate is reduced to a single symbolic issue: quotas on private company boards. Haven't we gotten any further than this? To quota a few, an extreme small percentage, the highest elite. It will not solve the gender equality problems faced by 250 million women across Europe. Indeed, studies have shown that where quotas have been applied on company boards, it is always the same women who get more assignments, not more women who are given assignments. On the other hand, in companies that achieve gender equality on a voluntary basis, where the company is more prosperous, has higher returns and has more women at the top. If we are to tackle the problems of gender equality, we need more women working, more women who become financially independent – that we encourage more women to own and that more women are allowed to live free from violence.  Because I know a whole generation of young women who are ambitious and driven, who want to show what they are made of, and they do not just want to sit on company boards; they want to lead the companies. So let us not put our legs off for these young women, and not introduce quotas and reduce their ambitions to their gender.

name: Lara Wolters (S&D).
text: – Mr President, seven years of inaction have given us more evidence of what we essentially already knew, which is that self—regulation and laissez—faire ultimately fail to bring more diversity to our boardrooms. Today the four countries in the EU with a binding quota have 23.6 percentage points more women on non—executive boards than those 11 with no rules whatsoever. Not only is that at odds with gender equality, a core principle of the EU of course, it’s also a waste of talent, and not only is it a waste of talent, it’s a bad business case because we know that diverse companies do better.  Parliament understood this seven years ago, the Commission understands this and the majority of Member States today understand this. There are of course a few sad exceptions and my country and yours, Mr Roth, are amongst them. But I urge you again – and you said it very well – I urge the German Presidency, and not Germany, to take leadership here at last and to fulfil its political, its moral and its institutional duty to us all.

name: Monica Semedo (Renew).
text: – Mr President, looking at our EU financial institutions you can see that governing boards are male-dominated. That is why I co-authored the Renew Europe principles to help achieve gender balance in the nomination process.  This problem is mirrored in the private sector where women face the same barriers. We should encourage companies to promote diversity and they should choose the best qualified candidates, and honestly speaking, I would not like to be appointed only because I’m a woman, because I’m young or because I’m black. So in order to have more qualified female candidates, we have to foster financial and entrepreneurial skills from an early age.  I urge the Commissioner, it’s time to get rid of outdated views in our society and work towards a future where women – and men – truly have the same opportunities.

name: France Jamet (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European directive on gender balance on boards is probably one of the most aberrant documents I have read. You explain to us that companies should be subject to quotas on the grounds that "male-dominated councils are much more likely to be marked by narrow conformity". I will not have time to discuss here the form: the absurd principle of quotas. But I'll get back to basics. In your opinion, conformism has a sex. Open-mindedness, intelligence, empathy, etc. would have a gender. Well, when it comes to discriminating stereotypes, you're doing well there! Ladies and gentlemen, the European economy is collapsing, the world is becoming more and more dangerous, the big publicly traded companies are blurring us, relocating, putting pressure on governments, doing tax, social and environmental dumping and putting thousands of people, men and women, out of work. And all you care about is the gender of decision-makers on boards... However, I do not see any more non-conformism, nor indeed success in the globalist austerity policy imposed by Mrs von der Leyen or Mrs Merkel. You can see that gender diversity does not mechanically lead to diversity of ideas.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, it is beyond doubt that diversity of company boards is an asset, because diversity means that the board members have different views, different backgrounds, different experiences. So, the question then is why was diversity of company boards then doing better than it is today? I believe that one problem is hidden criteria for the selection of board members, where still the stereotype is a certain type of white man, and this should now be broken somehow. We have seen, for instance, in Finland, which has so far chosen the way of self-regulation, that you come to a certain degree: you can have 29% of women on listed company boards, but you won’t get that further with self-regulation. I believe that we should not be satisfied with that low number, and that’s why we need this European regulation. I also very much believe that, because women are barely represented in those committees in companies which actually choose board members, this has to be corrected. In Finland, only 14% are women on this kind of body in companies.

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, it has been seven years, seven years since our Parliament voted for the mandatory increase in the share of women on boards, when they are vastly under-represented. Seven years to achieve a meagre target of 40% women, and how many more years before parity. Seven years since non-binding incentives failed due to lack of regulation. Seven years we have been trying to impose the obvious, except to consider that women are inherently less capable than men. Seven years since the European Council died and three terms of MEPs have been held here in the meantime. Seven years lost because a handful of machos refuse to move the little finger. Seven years lost because, as always, women's rights come last and are considered a negligible detail. Seven years lost because some men stubbornly cling to their circle of power. So I ask you, since seven years have not been enough for you to parity on the boards of directors, how many more centuries will it take before the revaluation of the feminized professions, equal pay between women and men, equality before parenthood? I say to you right now, we will not wait more and certainly not seven years to achieve the equality that is due to us.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the post-corona age, it is very important that we keep women on board, both literally and figuratively. Figuratively, because it was the women who were predominantly on the front line to fight the virus, but also literally bring it on board, by giving women a voice on the boards of listed companies.  In 2020, women will still be under-represented. Only three out of ten members of the boards are women. In some Member States, this is less than one in ten. And only 7.5% of CEOs are women. Countries such as France and Belgium show that good legislation does make a difference. More women on the board means a boost, an enrichment of companies. This is shown by numerous studies by the ILO and the OECD. This talent, this source of expertise and creativity, we must now tap into. There is an urgent need for a different corporate culture, where women and men take matters into their own hands together. We must strive for a society where quotas are not necessary and equal representation is evident. But as long as this is not the case, we need clear legislation. It is therefore time for the Member States in the Council to pull the issue out of the freezer and make the EU à point for gender equality, including on the boards of directors.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The women-on-board policy is something of a cough juice – a cough juice for a society that is not in balance. It's not in balance, we all know it. This cough juice is supposed to help balance occurs where there is currently imbalance. The fact that men always pick men when positions are filled is based on the principle of similarity. But that does not help us as a society. As a German speaker today, I would like to deliberately name the elephant in the room that I was still missing out on: it is also Germany, it is also my country that is blocking the women-on-board directive. I would like to say it very specifically here: it is Angela Merkel who is blocking her. I hope – and I hope she will hear the speech tomorrow, she will listen to it – i would like Angela Merkel to take her foot off the brake pedal of the women-on-boards directive. I hope that she will go ahead, that she will make it clear, as the current leader of the Presidency, that it is a sign of respect for who gives women participation – at every point. It's a sign of respect. We deserve it.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, twenty-five years ago, in China, the world made a promise: equal rights between men and women and equality for all women and girls on the planet. Equal opportunities between men and women are also at our core in the European Union: it is a truly reflection of who we are. It is also set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union; the United Nations has encouraged, in order to strike a balance in decision-making, to take initiatives and to take temporary measures to speed up this process. There is also the Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2025. And the Securities and Exchange Commission also revised the code of good conduct in order to accelerate that balance in decision-making positions. Not having women on the non-executive board of directors of publicly traded companies is losing economic growth, losing prosperity and losing competitiveness. Having them strengthens democracy, strengthens the rule of law, strengthens the proper functioning of this democracy, and also significantly reduces the pay gap and the labour gap. There is no doubt that all diversity, all talents and abilities of all men and women must be harnessed in that world. We need inclusive leadership for new challenges, not just demographics. New challenges need inclusiveness, innovation, sustainability. We are leaders in gender equality in the European Union because, of the twenty leading countries, there are fourteen that are Member States, but none have yet had full inclusion. I therefore encourage the Commission to co-edit, break stereotypes, encourage women to be entrepreneurs and to achieve a fairer world.

name: Maria-Manuel Leitão-Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in 2017, in Portugal there were 12% of women in the management bodies of listed companies. That same year we adopted a law in our Parliament which required quotas and in 2019 the percentage of women was 22% in executive positions.  I recall the arguments put forward against the law, that there were no competent women, in particular for companies in the financial sector - to assess by the 2008 crisis men also did not show great competence - that women did not have management experience, but if they do not occupy the positions as they can have experience? That the women were not available, but how was the invitation made to them? Come on, think about it, this is hard and your kids are going to need you, it's not going to ruin your personal life. And finally, that we would move forward without quotas, through dialogue and self-regulation, which we know is not true.  It's time to get over this impasse. I want the German Presidency to do so, but if that does not happen, I hope that the Portuguese Presidency will be inspired by its own success case and find the majority needed to overcome this blockade that has lasted for too long.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I think it is a shame that the directive has been stuck for several years in the Commission. It is a shame that in the 21st century there are politicians who believe that a woman's place is at home. It is a shame that women who have succeeded – often with the support of other women – today forget about these women.  Research shows that companies with at least 30% of women on boards perform better financially and are less prone to crisis. And we all know and see that many women, although better than men, often have no chance of taking a leadership position precisely because of the traditional perception of the role of women and the fact that part of society constantly thinks that leadership should be held by men.  Covid-19 revolutionized the style of work, remote work challenged in many cases such male leadership. Today, the company counts such holistic management, relationship building, communication, as well as understanding and empathy. I think that women are masters in such management, and I believe that in this term of office together, Commissioner, we will be able to break through this glass ceiling. And this glass ceiling we will be able to pierce with the support of men, wise men, and with the support of all strong, responsible women. And that is what I wish us and all European women.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Last year, the boards of the largest listed companies in the EU Member States consisted of 72% men. 72 percent men. The representation of women on these boards is shamefully low. For us Swedish Social Democrats, this issue is very important. It is a question of equality, but it is just as much a question of better decision-making.  It benefits our businesses and it benefits our communities. We would increase the employment rate. If the EU were to be more equal, more than 10 million new jobs would be created, and the EU's gross domestic product per capita would grow by almost 10%. This is what the European Institute for Gender Equality says. What are we waiting for? We Swedish Social Democrats support the directive on gender balance. Use women's skills and knowledge now. I don't want to wait.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Mr President! The European Union has become a strong economy by virtue of our diversity. Diversity is a key part of the EU's cultural DNA. That is why I can understand why many people do not understand why diversity on some boards is so slow, especially when you look at the number of women in relation to the number of men. But even though I am a woman and born in the sign of the fish, I am therefore opposed to quotas. Never will I put up with being elected to anything just because I'm a woman. Never will I, as a former business owner, allow myself, as a Member of parliament, to interfere in how Europe's business owners should put together their boards. They know that best themselves.  But apparently they can get smarter. Because there are indeed many advantages to having women on boards that too many companies either do not know about or know how to get activated in their industry. Benefits that can make the EU economy even stronger, and we need that more than ever before. Therefore, will the Commission and the Council do not do more to spread knowledge about the benefits of diversity on boards? Let's hear more about the clever carrots instead of the symbolism whips.

name: Marianne Vind (S&D).
text: Mr President! We will write the year 2020. But sometimes it can feel like we're still alive in the early 20th century. The proportion of women on the boards of the largest European listed companies now stands at 28%, and on many boards there are no women at all. This also applies in publicly owned companies. Imagine if it was the other way around. The competent women are out there and they are many, but they don't come into play. It's a huge waste of talent. It's not just that there's equality at the top - studies also show that it's good for the corporate bottom line. After all, we already have quotas, because there are employee representatives on the public limited company boards. So we know it. Therefore, as a member of S&D, I would like and urge both the Commission and the Council to pursue certain fixed targets, at least 40% of each sex on Europe's boards.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you so much for your continuous support in our efforts towards a fair gender balance at decision—making levels. With regards to the legal basis, clarification on the legal basis will always be provided, and we continuously engage with Member States. So this is a question of will. Do we want equality for all at the European level or don’t we? This is what Council has to decide. If we believe we are a Union of equality, then the answer is natural: we need an EU directive. And yes, you are right: yes, we do need more men to support this, and this is not something about women only. It’s about better decision—making, because there is more diversity and there is strength in that diversity. We’ve been hearing how companies which have a diversified management, or at board level, make more profit, and this is data which we have. This is not a hunch that we have, this is scientific data which we have. So having qualified men and women at the decision—making levels means that there is the perspective of both halves of the population, and we are not wasting a lot of talent which is available. This is human capital we are talking about here, but we are wasting so much. There’s so much research: ILO, OECD, and they all point in the same direction. But this will not happen on its own. That is why I say we need the directive. We have waited and waited, and it didn’t happen. It will not happen naturally, unless we want to wait another hundred years – and I don’t think that is what we want, and so that is why we need to introduce mechanisms to make it happen. And when it happens, we won’t need the mechanism any more. This is not something forever. This is for some years, until we get that gender balance, and then we will not need the mechanism any more. I reiterate: diversity is a strength, and we are wasting that strength by not using the full potential of the many qualified women which we have. It’s really a shame, and I really can’t understand. I’ve tried to understand. I’ve listened to all the arguments here, and it’s not about wanting to be in the boardroom. It’s about making use of all this potential and working together, and making use of this strength in diversity. So really, I think that people who want to understand this can understand it. I will keep on working with the Member States who have yet to be convinced that this is the right way forward. But equality will not be achieved unless we act decisively. We’ve been tottering on this for far too long: too many years. I want to use this platform which you have given me today to urge Council to act now. Women have waited long enough.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you again for pointing out that I am speaking for the Council and not for my government alone. I am extremely grateful to the honourable Member for mentioning once again an important point. If we regard gender equality and equality only as an exclusive matter for women, then we will all fail. It must be about men and women fulfilling their responsibilities. That is why, like you, I am just as pleased with every man who is taking part in this debate here today. I also have the impression that there is a broad consensus – at least in large parts of the European Parliament, but also for the Council and, of course, for the Commission – to really develop the European Union into a Union of Equality. Admittedly, there is still a controversial debate in the Council on legal requirements. I have the impression that this has been expressed again here in the European Parliament, but at the same time I have also highlighted positive examples. And I would like to remind you once again that last year we also took a major step forward with the directive on work-life balance. Because we all know – not just women – how difficult it is still in everyday life to combine work and family life. This is also evident at this very moment in this serious crisis.  When asked what concrete steps the Presidency intends to take in the coming weeks, I would like to remind you, on the one hand, that on 13 October – unfortunately in a video conference – there will be a debate between The Ministers for Labour and Social Affairs on gender equality in the labour market, and an informal Council meeting in November will once again be about gender equality with the relevant ministers. We really want to take this issue forward in our Presidency – and that is why I understand this debate as a tailwind for the Council's commitment. I would also like to draw attention once again to another project which is very close to my heart, because the initiative was also developed from within the centre of the Council. This is something that we do not know in my country and in most other countries, namely gender mainstreaming. We have introduced this for the multiannual financial framework. This is at least part of our negotiating mandate that all European Union expenditure should be checked to see whether it benefits men and women equally. This is a major paradigm shift, which also makes one thing clear: we must not underestimate the value of Europe, namely the value of learning from each other and with each other, of moving forward without prejudice and of making the strengths that others have become each other's strengths at some point. Thank you for this inspiring debate and thank you for being there today.
